There is no difference between 语境 (yǔjìng) in Chinese and context in English.
There is no difference between 无花果 (wúhuāguǒ) in Chinese and fig in English.
糊 (hú) can be used as an adjective meaning blurry or to describe the consistency of certain foods (like porridge).
近音 (jìnyīn) mean words which are pronounced nearly identically. They can also mean homophones.
圈外人 (quānwàirén) can refer to anyone who is outside of a particular social circle or field.
There is no difference between 西藏 (xīzàng) in Chinese and Tibet in English.
There is no difference between 荆棘 (jīngjí) in Chinese and thorns in English, although it can be used metaphorically, unlike thorns in English.
There is no difference between 鑄鐵 (zhùtiě) in Chinese and cast iron in English.
训诫 (xùnjiè) means to admonish or reprimand. It implies an authoritative figure giving a warning or criticism.
成人 (chéngrén) means adult. Note that this has no sexual connotations in Chinese like it does in some English contexts.
This is the plural of 朋友 (péngyou). Although 们 (men) can often be omitted, when it is present it emphasizes that you are talking to all of your friends, not just some of them.
尤其是 (yóuqíshì) is used for emphasis, to highlight something in particular. It translates to "especially" or "particularly". It is somewhat formal.

巡抚 (xúnfǔ) was a high-ranking official in imperial China, responsible for overseeing a province. There is no perfect single word translation; depending on the context, it can be translated as "governor", "inspector-general", or "viceroy".
富裕 (fùyù) means wealthy or affluent.
崩溃 (bēngkuì) can mean to collapse (both literally and figuratively).
燃料 (ránliào) means fuel.
表示 (biǎoshì) has several meanings including: to express, to show, to indicate, to represent, to state, or to mean.
公司 (gōngsī) means company.
印象 (yìnxiàng) means impression.
晒黑 (shài hēi) means to get a suntan, or to be sunburned. Note that it is made up of the two words 晒 (to sunbathe) and 黑 (black).
隐喻 (yǐnyù) means metaphor.
海鲈 (hǎilú) means sea bass.
高兴 (gāoxìng) means happy.  It is similar to 开心 (kāixīn).  高兴 is generally more formal.

When referring to the sea in general, 海 is typically used. However, when speaking about a specific sea, like the South China Sea, the term 洋 (yáng) is used, e.g., 南中国海 (Nán Zhōngguó Hǎi) is incorrect, whereas 南中国洋 (Nán Zhōngguó Yáng) is correct.  Bear in mind that this rule doesn't apply to oceans, e.g. the Pacific Ocean is 太平洋 (Tài Píng Yáng) and the Atlantic Ocean is 大西洋 (Dà Xī Yáng).
This is a more formal word, typically used in tourist brochures and official contexts.  For everyday conversations, use 看风景 (kàn fēngjǐng) or simply 玩儿 (wánr).

外人 has two meanings.  The first is "outsider," referring to someone outside a particular group or organization. The second, more subtle meaning, is "stranger," specifically in the context of family or close relationships. It can be used to refer to someone not considered part of the immediate family circle. For example, if someone brings their boyfriend home to meet their family for the first time, the family might say something like, "不要在外人面前这样" (bùyào zài wàirén miànqián zhèyàng) meaning "don't act like that in front of strangers/outsiders".
This refers exclusively to tourists who are visiting from *outside* the country.  For domestic travelers, use 旅行者 (lǚxíng zhě).

While 火盆 literally translates to "fire basin," it often refers specifically to the braziers used for warmth in colder regions or during winter. These braziers are traditionally used in Chinese households.
This word isn't inherently negative like "exaggerate" can be in English.  It can be used to describe something impressive or extraordinary, carrying a sense of awe or admiration.
Make sure to include the 牌 (pái, cards).  Just saying 塔罗 (tǎluó) sounds incomplete.
This specifically refers to the swordfish. Don't confuse it with other fish that might have "sword" in their English name.
In biology, this specifically refers to cells or tissues that haven't specialized or differentiated yet.  More broadly, it describes something that's not yet developed or categorized clearly.
例子 is more accurately translated as "example," not "story" or "case".  While a 例子 could be part of a story, it shouldn't be used interchangeably.

叫 has many meanings. It most commonly means "to call" or "to be called." However, it can also be used when ordering food in a restaurant. When ordering food, using 叫 is more common and natural than 点 (diǎn), which is often seen in textbooks. For example, one would say, "我要叫一个宫保鸡丁" rather than "我要点一个宫保鸡丁."
暖气 specifically refers to central heating.  For other forms of heating, like space heaters, use other words like 加热器 (jiārèqì).
This word carries a slightly more negative connotation than "flirt" in English, suggesting a more frivolous or even insincere intent.  Consider the context carefully.
This emphasizes the complete depletion or exhaustion of something.  Use it when something is *totally* used up, not just partially diminished.
This term is generally neutral, like "Asian people" in English.  Be mindful of context to avoid any unintended stereotyping.
脆弱 describes both physical and emotional vulnerability.  It can refer to fragile objects or a person's sensitive emotional state.
This introduces a new topic related to the previous discussion.  It's similar to "speaking of..." in English.
This can refer to both a physical mailbox and an email inbox. Context is essential for distinguishing between the two meanings.

了解 means "to understand" or "to know about" something or someone. It focuses on having general knowledge or awareness.  It is not as strong as 知道(zhīdào), which means "to know" a fact or piece of information.
This specifically means "to take off glasses."  For putting on glasses, use 戴眼镜 (dài yǎnjìng).
乡村 refers to rural areas in general.  For a specific village, use 村庄 (cūnzhuāng).
This can refer to any kind of powder, including cosmetic powder, medicine powder, or even dust.
残酷 emphasizes the callous and inhumane nature of an act, often involving violence or suffering. It's a stronger word than simply "cruel."

The words 低 and 高 should not be considered as absolute measurements but rather as comparative indicators.  低 means something is relatively less intense or lower than the average or another reference point. Similarly, 高 denotes that something is more intense or higher than a certain threshold or benchmark.
事业 refers to a long-term career or profession, emphasizing a sense of purpose and dedication.  It's not just any job.

批评 often carries a more serious and formal tone than the English word "criticize," often implying an official reprimand or judgment.  For more casual criticism, use other words like  说…不好 (shuō...bù hǎo) or  挑剔 (tiāoti).
教练 is a general term for "coach."  For specific sports, more specific terms might be used. For example, 足球教练 (zúqiú jiàoliàn) for a soccer coach.

万圣节 (Wànshèngjié) is a direct translation of "All Saints' Day," a Christian holiday.  For Halloween, which is celebrated on October 31st, use the term 万圣节前夜 (Wànshèngjié qiányè) meaning "All Hallows' Eve."
半年 literally translates to "half a year," which is six months. It's important to note that it doesn't necessarily specify *which* six months. It can refer to any six-month period within a year.
失去 (shīqù) means "to lose" in a broad sense. It can refer to losing physical objects, abstract things like opportunities, or even people through death or separation.
所在 (suǒzài) means "location" or "whereabouts."  It is a relatively formal word. For more casual conversation, use 地方 (dìfang) or 在哪儿 (zài nǎr).

前苏联 (qián Sūlián) means "the former Soviet Union."  Be mindful of the historical context when using this term, as it refers to the period before its dissolution in 1991.  For the current Russian Federation, use 俄罗斯 (Éluósī) or 俄国 (Éguó).
注册 (zhùcè) means to register or enroll.  It can be used in various contexts, such as registering for a website, enrolling in a school, or registering a company.
软腭化 (ruǎnéhuà) is a linguistic term referring to velarization, a phonetic process where the back of the tongue is raised towards the soft palate.
清真寺 (qīngzhēnsì) refers specifically to a mosque, a place of worship for Muslims.
形容词 (xíngróngcí) is the term for "adjective."
至少 (zhìshǎo) means "at least."
轻声 (qīngshēng) in linguistics refers to the neutral tone in Mandarin Chinese. It's also used to describe speaking softly.  Context differentiates the meaning.
违背 (wéibèi) means "to violate," "to go against," or "to disobey." It often refers to rules, principles, or promises.
一首诗 (yī shǒu shī) means "one poem."  The measure word 首 (shǒu) is used for poems and songs.
直觉 (zhíjué) means "intuition."
冬眠 (dōngmián) refers to hibernation.
国际 (guójì) means "international."
邮件 (yóujiàn) means "email" or "mail."
流 (liú) has many meanings including "to flow," "stream," "current," "class" (as in a category or type), "to shed tears," among others.
人脉 (rénmài) refers to one's network of contacts or connections, often in a professional or social context.  It's similar to "guanxi" but is a slightly more formal term.
读书会 (dúshū huì) refers to a book club.
知识 (zhīshi) means "knowledge."
方面 (fāngmiàn) means "aspect" or "respect."  It's often used to discuss different facets of a topic or situation.
响 (xiǎng) means "to make a sound," "to ring," or "loud." It can also be used as an adjective to describe a sound as loud or resonant.
This word is both a noun and a verb.

These words can be used to describe time.  For example, 长假 (chángjià) means "long vacation," and 短假 (duǎnjià) means "short vacation."  They're also used with other time words like  长/短期 (cháng/duǎnqí) - long/short term, 长/短时间 (cháng/duǎn shíjiān) - long/short time.
Many English speakers learning Chinese confuse this word (sweater) with 毛巾 (máojīn - towel). Be careful!

This word is more formal than "假设" (jiǎshè) and is more commonly used in written Chinese.  They're largely interchangeable, though 假定 sometimes leans more toward "suppose" while 假设 is closer to "assume."
This phrase specifically refers to a vegan diet.  Just saying 素食 (sùshí - vegetarian) doesn't necessarily imply veganism, as some vegetarians consume dairy and eggs.
This describes a place crowded with people.  If you want to say traffic is congested, use 堵车 (dǔchē).
While this can mean "to relax," it can also mean "to loosen" as in "to loosen one's grip."
This word can be used as a verb meaning "to cross" or "to intersect." It can also be used as an adjective to describe things placed across each other.
世界 can also mean “all over the world” e.g., 世界闻名 (shìjiè wénmíng), world-famous
A similar word is 水族馆 (shuǐzúguǎn). However, 水族馆 is much larger and includes fish and other marine creatures. It's an aquarium, while 鱼缸 is a fish tank.
Make sure not to confuse this with 助学金 (zhùxuéjīn), which is financial aid.  奖学金 is specifically a scholarship awarded based on merit.
This word emphasizes duration, like "always" or "forever."  If you want to emphasize an unchanging state, use 一直 (yīzhí), which means "continuously."

While this often translates to "people," it carries a more specific connotation in Chinese, often referring to the citizens of a country, especially in a political context.  If you simply mean "people" in general, 人们 (rénmen) or 人 (rén) are more common.
This term is specifically for judges in a court of law.  Don't confuse it with 裁判 (cáipàn), which refers to a referee or umpire in a sporting event.
This can mean both "adventure" (as a noun) and "to take a risk/to venture" (as a verb).
This translates directly to "sense of humor."  There isn't a single word equivalent to "humorous" in this context. You'd describe someone *as having* 幽默感 or say something *is* 幽默 (yōumò - humorous).
This character alone generally refers to sound in general, or a musical note.  It is a component in more specific words like 音节 (yīnjié - syllable), 音调 (yīndiào - tone), and 音乐 (yīnyuè - music).
This word specifically refers to a gourd.  While it can be used figuratively, its primary meaning is the plant itself or objects made from it.
This word can sometimes carry a slightly negative connotation, so be mindful of the context.  原住民 (yuánzhùmín) is a more neutral and respectful term.
This focuses on giving someone courage or inspiring them to act.  It's different from 支持 (zhīchí - support), which implies providing practical help or resources.
This word refers to converting between units, like currency or measurements.  It is more specific than simply "changing" something.
This means to display or exhibit something, often to a wider audience, similar to "show off."  It's distinct from 给…看 (gěi... kàn), which simply means "to show" someone something.
Remember to capitalize the "Z" in Zangzu when writing in English, as it refers to a specific ethnic group.  The same applies to other ethnicities like Hanzu (汉族).
This word refers to someone's temperament or disposition, often their natural or inherent character.  It's deeper than just their current mood.
This can be both a noun ("typical example") and an adjective ("typical" or "representative").
This means "to care about" or "to be concerned about," but it doesn't carry the romantic implications sometimes associated with "care" in English.
This word means uneasy, anxious, or restless.  It's different from  不舒服 (bù shūfu), which refers to physical discomfort.
This word means "vowel." The counterpart is 辅音 (fǔyīn), "consonant."
This construction is a concise way to express a range of two to three years.
This word refers to internal friction or conflict within a group or organization, leading to wasted resources and reduced efficiency.

This can mean "north," "north side," or "northern part."  The specific meaning depends on context.  For example, 学校北边 (xuéxiào běibian) could mean either "north of the school" or "the north side of the school."
This means "to study martial arts." It implies ongoing learning and practice, not just a one-off experience.
This word refers to a test or trial, often one that is difficult or challenging. It can be used for both concrete tests and more abstract trials of character.
Remember to capitalize the first letter of Hindi when referring to the language in English.
This is more commonly known as "tilapia" in English.
This noun refers to comparability. It discusses whether or not two things are suitable for comparison.
This word refers to a person's native place or place of origin.  It is often used in official documents and registrations.
This word refers to commerce or business in general. It's broader than just a single shop or company.
This word refers specifically to a theater for plays or operas.  电影院 (diànyǐngyuàn) is used for cinemas.
This word can mean both "to exist" and "existence."  It also has a more nuanced meaning of "to be present" or "to occur."
Remember to capitalize both "New" and "York" when referring to the city in English.
This linguistic term translates to "dental consonant" in English.
This refers specifically to summer vacation.  寒假 (hánjià) is winter vacation.
This can mean "to exchange" physical items, but also "to exchange" ideas or information, like in a conversation.
This can refer to a theory, but also to the theoretical aspect of something, in contrast to the practical aspect (实践 shíjiàn).
This refers specifically to natural light, as opposed to artificial light (人造光 rénzàoguāng).
Don't confuse this with 指甲 (zhǐjia), which refers to fingernails *or* toenails. 脚趾 specifically means "toe."
This refers to grassland or prairie.  It's different from 草地 (cǎodì), which refers to a smaller grassy area, like a lawn.
This word implies maintaining a state or condition, rather than just keeping something in a physical location.
This word implies exerting control or restraint over something, often with difficulty.  It's stronger than simply managing or directing.
A similar phrase is 不起作用 (bù qǐ zuòyòng).  没效果 is slightly more colloquial.
While 乐器 can refer to any musical instrument, it often excludes the human voice in Chinese.  If you want to include the voice, you could say “乐器和人声”.

This describes the state of an animal's fur standing on end due to fear or anger.  It can also be used figuratively to describe a person who is extremely angry or agitated.  A close English equivalent might be "bristling".
While this can refer to any cage, it’s more commonly used for birdcages. For larger animal enclosures, other words like 兽笼 (shòulóng) might be more appropriate.
This term is relatively modern and often used in formal contexts.
This word is quite visceral and graphic.  It describes the process of decomposition, often with unpleasant connotations.
Specifically refers to the green pea.  If you want to talk about snow peas or snap peas, those are 荷兰豆 (hélándòu).
Refers to the financial district in New York City and is often used metaphorically to represent American finance or capitalism.
Emphasizes authenticity or genuineness.  It’s often used to distinguish something real from something fake or superficial.
Refers specifically to the 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac.
A more colloquial way to say this is 出汗 (chūhàn).
Short for 青年旅舍 (qīngnián lǚshè), which means youth hostel.
Implies a belief in someone's reliability and integrity.
More commonly used for animals than humans.  For humans, 生孩子 (shēng háizi) or 分娩 (fēnmiǎn) are more common.  When referring to plants, 生 is often used to describe sprouting or germination.
Implies moving one's residence or place of business.
Can mean "nature," "natural," or "naturally" depending on the context.
In addition to its scientific meaning, 元素 can also refer to a basic component or factor of something.
Specifically refers to a group chat on WeChat.
Often followed by a verb phrase indicating the action that is worth doing.
Indicates suitability or appropriateness.
Generally refers to a room within a house or building.
Refers to fish that live in the deep sea, often with unusual adaptations.
Refers to a postdoctoral researcher.
A colloquial expression meaning "out of battery." The emoji is often included.
Colloquial and commonly used for sending messages or sharing content online.
Refers to conducting an interview, typically for journalistic purposes.
The term for "bisexual."  Be aware that LGBTQ+ topics can be sensitive in some Chinese-speaking contexts.
Refers specifically to the summer season.
Indicates that something has already happened.
Refers to a specific style of Chinese calligraphy.
Refers to ancient Greece.
Means "to spend time."
Refers to a group of people sharing common characteristics or interests.
Refers to stocks or shares in a company.
Means "screenshot."
Describes a positive and hopeful outlook.
Refers to a viewpoint or opinion.
Implies manipulating or controlling something, often with negative connotations.
Means "unreasonable" or "illogical."
Describes something that is easy or relaxed.
Means "otherwise."
Means "to embody" or "to reflect."
Refers to quantity or amount.
Means "to remind."
Has multiple meanings depending on context.  Make sure the context is clear to avoid misunderstandings.
Means "to save" or "to preserve."
Refers to a comb.
Refers to the Russian language.
Refers to a reason or justification.

Means to appease or pacify someone who is upset or agitated. It often involves soothing words and actions to calm their emotions and restore stability.  Similar words include 平息 (píngxī - to quell, subdue), 抚慰 (fǔwèi - to comfort, console), and 安慰 (ānwèi - to comfort, console).  安抚 carries a slightly stronger connotation of calming a volatile situation, whereas 安慰 is more general.
This is how you say "percent" in Chinese. Note that 百分之五十 is sometimes abbreviated to five percent (五成 - wǔchéng).

This can refer to a show, program, or item on a program. It also has the specific meaning of a performance or act within a larger show or event. For example, a singing performance at a school talent show could be called a 节目.  It can be used for both television/radio programs and live performances.

This means "to mix up" or "to confuse".  It often implies causing confusion through mixing things up, or being confused due to similar elements. The result of 搞混 is often described using  混淆 (hùnxiáo - to confuse, mix up).  A similar word is 弄混 (nòng hùn).

Refers to a narrow alley or lane, typically found in traditional residential areas of Chinese cities, especially Beijing. Often associated with close-knit communities and traditional architecture.  There is no perfect English translation, but it is often translated as "alleyway", "lane", or "hutong" itself.

Covers a range of meanings related to biting, including nibbling, gnawing, and even stinging (by insects). The specific meaning depends on context.  For example,  蚊子咬了我 (wénzi yǎo le wǒ) means "A mosquito bit me," while  狗咬了人 (gǒu yǎo le rén) means "A dog bit someone."
Specifically refers to uploading files or data to a network or online platform. The opposite is 下载 (xiàzài) for downloading.
Refers generally to a Buddhist temple.  While it can sometimes refer to temples of other religions, it most commonly refers to Buddhist ones.  道观 (dàoguàn) is used for Taoist temples.

This term emphasizes conjecture and speculation based on limited information or intuition. It implies a degree of uncertainty and may not be based on concrete evidence.  Close synonyms include 推测 (tuīcè - to speculate, infer) and 猜测 (cāicè - to guess, conjecture), but 猜想 may imply a more playful or less serious guess.

Means "generally," "overall," or "on the whole," and is used to summarize a general trend or impression. It's similar to  总的来说 (zǒng de lái shuō), but 总体上 is more formal and often used in written Chinese.

Refers to an abbreviation formed by shortening a word or phrase.  This can be an acronym, initialism, or simply a truncated form of the original word. For example,  "USA" is a 缩写 of "United States of America."

Has several meanings: fresh (as in food), new, novel, and refreshing.  It can describe something that is recently produced or harvested (新鲜的蔬菜 - xiānxian de shūcài - fresh vegetables), something new and exciting (新鲜的想法 - xiānxian de xiǎngfǎ - fresh ideas), or even the feeling of invigoration (呼吸新鲜空气 - hūxī xiānxian kōngqì - to breathe fresh air).

Means "to give a 20% discount."  打折 generally means "to give a discount," with the number indicating the remaining percentage. For example, 打九折 is a 10% discount.  A 50% discount is often referred to as 打五折 or simply 半价 (bànjià - half price).

Refers to the state or quality of being continuous and uninterrupted. Often used in technical or academic contexts to describe processes, data, or phenomena that unfold without breaks or interruptions.

Refers to rights, powers, and privileges granted by law or custom. It often refers to fundamental rights, such as freedom of speech or the right to a fair trial. It is distinct from  权力 (quánlì - power, authority) which refers to the capacity to influence or control others.

Means "to come from" or "to originate from". It's similar to 从 (cóng), but 来自 emphasizes the origin or source of something, while 从 is more general and can simply mean "from."  For instance, 来自 usually describes where a person was born or grew up (e.g., 我来自中国 - Wǒ láizì Zhōngguó - I come from China), while 从 is often for where you are currently traveling from (e.g., 我从北京来 - Wǒ cóng Běijīng lái - I come from Beijing).

Describes someone who is aloof, distant, and seemingly unapproachable.  It combines 高傲 (gāo'ào - arrogant, proud) and 冷漠 (lěngmò - indifferent, apathetic).  It's often used to describe a personality type, especially in online and popular culture.

Can refer to a written work in a broad sense.  Can include essays, articles, literary pieces, and even online posts. It doesn't specifically refer to news articles (新闻 - xīnwén) or research papers (论文 - lùnwén), though it can encompass them in some contexts.

Means "to cut" with scissors or shears.  It implies a clean cut, often through paper, cloth, or hair.  It's distinct from  切 (qiē - to cut, slice) which usually involves a knife and is used for food or other materials.
Specifically refers to spiders.  Other spider-like creatures, such as mites or ticks, have different names.

Refers to aesthetic taste or judgment.  It encompasses a person's sense of beauty and their ability to appreciate art, music, and other forms of aesthetic expression.  It can be used as a noun (我的审美 - wǒ de shěnměi - my aesthetic) or a verb (审美这幅画 - shěnměi zhè fú huà - to appreciate this painting aesthetically).

This is actually the name of a traditional Chinese medicine formula (Xiao Chai Hu Tang). It shouldn't be confused with general references to firewood (柴 - chái) or herbs (generally referred to as 中药 - zhōngyào).
Specifically means "to lose hair," often in the context of hair loss or balding. It's different from  剪头发 (jiǎn tóufa - to cut hair) or  理发 (lǐfà - to get a haircut).
Describes a state of being calm, composed, and at ease, especially in the face of adversity or difficult situations.  It suggests a sense of acceptance and a lack of anxiety or fear.
Indicates advancement, improvement, or progress.  It can refer to tangible achievements or to personal growth and development.
A colloquial term for a wealthy person or "rich person".  More formal terms include 富人 (fùrén) or 富豪 (fùháo).
Means "indeed," "truly," or "certainly."  It's used to emphasize the truth or validity of a statement.  It can also be used to acknowledge something as a fact.

Can mean "to design," "to plan," or "to scheme."  It covers a broad range of creative and strategic activities, from fashion design to architectural planning to even crafting a plan or scheme (which can sometimes have negative connotations).
Refers to a race or ethnic group.  Be mindful of its sensitivity and use it carefully, as discussions about race can be delicate.
Means "subjective" as opposed to "objective." It emphasizes personal opinions, biases, and perspectives, rather than factual or impartial observations.

Means "to kill," but it's a more direct and forceful term than some synonyms. It can carry a more violent or negative connotation.  It's more intense than  杀害 (shāhài) which often suggests unlawful killing, or  死亡 (sǐwáng) which is a more general term for death.
Specifically refers to "hourly wage."  It's distinct from  月薪 (yuèxīn - monthly salary) or  年薪 (niánxīn - annual salary).
Refers to "Palo Santo," a type of fragrant wood traditionally used for spiritual purification and cleansing. It's not a general term for any sacred wood.
This refers to Zhejiang province in China.  Be aware of its proper pronunciation (Zhèjiāng).
Means "to dismantle," "to tear down," or "to take apart." It suggests deconstructing something that was previously assembled, often a structure or device.
Can mean "accident," "unexpected event," or "surprise."  The specific meaning depends on context, but it generally refers to something unforeseen.
Specifically means "elevator" or "lift."
Means "to bully," "to pick on," or "to take advantage of."  It suggests an act of aggression or intimidation against someone weaker.
Formally means "to dismiss from employment" or "to fire."  It's more formal than  开除 (kāichú) which also means "to fire" but can carry a stronger negative connotation.
Means "to go on foot," "to hike," or "to trek."  It emphasizes traveling by walking, often over a long distance or challenging terrain.
Specifically refers to a pronoun in grammar.
Refers to the academic study of language, encompassing various aspects such as phonetics, phonology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.
Means "to prompt," "to remind," or "to give a hint." It suggests offering a helpful piece of information or guidance.
Means "to appreciate," "to enjoy," or "to admire."  It often refers to appreciating art, music, or natural beauty.
Specifically means "eyeshadow."
Means "to discriminate against" or "discrimination." It refers to unfair or prejudicial treatment based on factors such as race, gender, religion, or sexual orientation.
Specifically means etymology, the study of the origin and historical development of words.
Refers to a mountain ridge, the long, narrow top of a mountain or mountain range.
Refers specifically to Chinese idioms, which are four-character expressions with figurative meanings.
Refers to a profession, occupation, or career.  It's a more formal term than  工作 (gōngzuò - work, job).

This is a neutral term and doesn't necessarily have negative connotations like "luxury goods" sometimes does in English.  More colloquial terms that *do* carry a negative connotation include  "奢侈" (shēchǐ - extravagance) and "豪华" (háohuá - luxurious, opulent).
A similar word is 性情 (xìngqíng). 性格 is more about one's inherent nature, whereas 性情 is more about their outward disposition.

This word refers to a person's preference to not attract attention to themselves, and it is generally seen as a positive trait in Chinese culture. It doesn't necessarily translate to humility but more closely aligns with modesty, unpretentiousness, and avoiding ostentation.  A person can be very successful and accomplished but still 低调.
When used with nouns, the measure word 个 is usually used.
This word is not commonly used. Most Chinese speakers refer to Greek as "希腊文" (Xīlà wén).
When used to mean "chat", the most common collocations are 聊聊天 (liáo liáotiān) and  聊一会儿 (liáo yīhuǐr).
Often refers to a small, independent company or a freelancer's workspace, often in creative industries. It doesn't always literally mean a "work room" as much as a small-scale operation.

This phrase describes a situation where there's no one to make decisions or control the situation. It implies a freedom from supervision, which might be positive or negative depending on context.  It also implies a lack of leadership.
While it can mean physical strength, 力量 is more often used to refer to abstract power, influence, or force.  For example, 政治力量 (zhèngzhì lìliàng) means political power.
While often translated as "Taoism," 道家 more specifically refers to the philosophical tradition, while 道教 (dàojiào) refers to the religious practices associated with Taoism.
A common collocation is 放假 (fàngjià), which means "to have a holiday/vacation."  For example,  暑假 (shǔjià - summer vacation) or 寒假 (hánjià - winter vacation).
This word can mean family or household. It can refer to the people in a family, the place where they live or both.
Often used online to indicate a desire to be among the first to see or comment on something.  Similar to "front row seats" or being at the "front of the line."
A colloquial term for instant noodles.  The full name is 方便面 (fāngbiàn miàn), but 泡面 is much more common in everyday speech.
This word describes a state of calmness, tranquility, and peace.  It can refer to both external circumstances and an internal emotional state.

This word refers to a distinguishing characteristic, usually in personality or character. It is slightly more formal than other words with similar meaning and thus carries more weight when discussing character or personality.
This word emphasizes one's social standing, role, or position within a community. It can also refer to legal status or official identity.
This word encompasses one's appearance, public persona, and the overall impression they make on others. It can refer to both individuals and organizations.
This word refers to an area on the outskirts of a city, often residential and less densely populated than the urban core.
This word refers to interior decoration and renovation, often involving significant changes to a space.  It is not as general as "decorating" in English.
This refers specifically to cuttlefish, not squid (鱿鱼 - yóuyú) or octopus (章鱼 - zhāngyú).
This refers specifically to paying for internet service, not other utilities.
This is the standard term for broccoli.
This is slang for a quick divorce, often occurring shortly after marriage.
This word describes a relationship characterized by kindness, goodwill, and mutual respect.
This personality type is generally viewed less favorably in Chinese culture than in some Western cultures.  It often carries connotations of shyness, reservedness, and a lack of social skills.
This word refers to resolving or dissolving a problem, often a conflict or misunderstanding, through communication and compromise.
This term specifically refers to part-time or temporary work, often for students or those seeking supplementary income.  It has a slightly less formal connotation than 工作 (gōngzuò).
This word describes a feeling of awkwardness, embarrassment, or social discomfort.
Be mindful of the distinction between 欧洲 (Ōuzhōu - Europe) and 欧盟 (Ōuméng - European Union), as not all European countries are part of the EU.
This refers to an electrical outlet or socket.
This term refers to serotonin.
This word refers to morality, ethics, and principles of right and wrong. It is a significant concept in Chinese culture.
This word can describe anything related to Western culture, including food, clothing, and lifestyle.
This word describes a feeling of exhilaration, satisfaction, or release, often after overcoming a challenge or expressing oneself freely.

This word can be used literally to describe being surrounded or encircled, but it can also be used figuratively to describe being overwhelmed or bombarded with something, such as information or emotions.
This term refers to a computer programmer or software developer.
This term refers to the prime minister of a country, particularly in a parliamentary system.  The president of a republic is called 总统 (zǒngtǒng).
When used with social media, this word means "to share" or "repost."
While 玫瑰 (méigui) can refer to roses in general, 玫瑰花 (méiguihuā) is the more common and specific term for rose flowers.
This word can mean "to prove," "to certify," or "proof/certificate."
This phrase describes someone who speaks with an accent, which can be either regional or foreign.
This term refers to a vampire.
This word refers to a famine or severe food shortage.
This word can refer to both the process of immigrating and the person who immigrates (an immigrant).
This is a derogatory term referring to someone who acts subservient or behaves like a slave.
This preposition means "about" or "concerning."
This word can refer to a wave (of water, sound, light, etc.), a period or spell of something, or a group of people.
This word can describe ripeness (of fruit), maturity (of a person), or sophistication (of a product or technology).
While literally meaning "hammer," 锤子 (chuízi) is also used as an exclamation of disbelief or frustration, similar to "bullshit!" or "no way!" It is considered vulgar slang.

认同 is more formal than 同意, and usually implies agreement on a deeper, more fundamental level, often involving values or beliefs.  It suggests accepting something as part of one's own identity or worldview.  同意 is more general and can be used for simple agreement or consent.  For example, you might 认同 a political philosophy, but simply 同意 to meet a friend for dinner.

好处 (hǎochù) is similar to the English word "benefit," but it carries a slightly more tangible connotation, referring to concrete advantages or gains. It implies receiving something good or desirable rather than merely being spared something negative.  It is suitable for concrete benefits like getting a discount or winning a prize, not necessarily more abstract ones.

While 年龄 technically means "age," it's often used where English speakers might say "How old are you?".  A more natural way to ask someone's age in casual conversation is 你多大了？(nǐ duō dà le?).  Using just 年龄 can sound a little stiff or formal.
版本 (bǎnběn) is usually used with software or documents. It would sound weird to use it with books, movies, or other products.

躺 (tǎng) emphasizes the posture of lying down horizontally.  It doesn't necessarily mean sleeping, just being in a reclined position.  If you want to express the action of going to bed to sleep, 睡觉 (shuìjiào) or 上床睡觉 (shàngchuáng shuìjiào) is more appropriate.

首选 (shǒuxuǎn) is generally used for things rather than people. It would sound odd to use 首选 to describe your preferred candidate in an election. For people, you'd likely use 最喜欢 (zuì xǐhuan) or other expressions of preference.
创业 (chuàngyè) specifically refers to starting a business, often with connotations of innovation and risk-taking.  It isn't used for simply getting a new job within an existing company.

潜力 (qiánlì) is used to describe the unrealized capacity for future development and success, focusing more on the unrealized development or skills that someone has. It is usually used in the context of talents and resources.

冲突 (chōngtū) implies a more serious disagreement or clash, often involving opposing forces or interests. It is more serious than a mere disagreement or argument, and usually includes direct confrontation.
灵魂 (línghún) refers to the spiritual or non-physical essence of a person, often associated with concepts of the afterlife or immortality. It has a religious or philosophical context.

形容 (xíngróng) is about describing the appearance, features, or qualities of something, not the actions or feeling of it. To describe an action or feeling, you can use 描写 (miáoxiě) or 描述 (miáoshù) which encompasses a broader range of description.

侵略 (qīnlüè) specifically refers to an act of invading or encroaching upon another's territory or rights, often by force. While "aggression" can be broader, encompassing various forms of hostile behavior, 侵略 always implies a violation of boundaries or sovereignty.
泡茶 (pào chá) refers specifically to the process of steeping tea leaves in hot water.  It doesn't refer to making other kinds of beverages.

对称 (duìchèn) is primarily used in mathematical or artistic contexts to describe objects or patterns that are identical on either side of a dividing line or plane. It implies a precise mirroring, not just a general similarity.

比方说 (bǐfāngshuō) introduces an example, similar to "for example" or "for instance."  However, it suggests a more specific or concrete illustration rather than a general category.  For broader examples, you might use 例如 (lìrú).
叫外卖 (jiào wàimài) specifically refers to ordering food for delivery.  It doesn't include picking up takeout food yourself.
烤箱 (kǎoxiāng) refers to an oven used for baking or roasting.  It's distinct from a microwave oven (微波炉 - wēibōlú).
落汤鸡 (luòtāngjī) describes someone who is completely drenched, like a "drowned rat." It's more vivid and informal than simply saying "wet."

压力 (yālì) can encompass both positive and negative stress.  While it often implies negative pressure, it can also refer to the motivating force of a challenge.  Context is key to understanding the specific meaning.

享受 (xiǎngshòu) emphasizes actively taking pleasure in something, often involving sensory or emotional gratification.  It implies a more deliberate and conscious savoring than simply feeling happy or content.
笔试 (bǐshì) refers specifically to a written examination, as opposed to an oral or practical test.
陌生人 (mòshēngrén) emphasizes complete unfamiliarity, someone you've never met before.  It's stronger than simply saying someone you don't know well.
恐怖片 (kǒngbùpiàn) specifically refers to horror films, not just any scary movie.
高血压 (gāoxuèyā) specifically refers to high blood pressure, a medical condition.
转发 (zhuǎnfā) is primarily used in the context of social media, meaning to share or repost something.
合肥话 (Héféi huà) refers specifically to the dialect spoken in Hefei, Anhui province.
消失 (xiāoshī) suggests a complete and often sudden disappearance, often without a trace.  It's stronger than simply saying something is gone or absent.
There is no difference between the use of 麝牛 in Chinese and Muskox in English.
人才 (réncái) refers to a person with special skills or talents, often implying they are valuable or in high demand.  It's more than just a capable person.
精致 (jīngzhì) describes something that is delicate, intricate, and often beautifully crafted.  It can apply to objects or, less commonly, to people's appearance or manners.
挤喉音 (jǐhóuyīn) is a linguistic term referring to ejective consonants, sounds produced by closing the glottis.
解释 (jiěshì) emphasizes clarifying or making something understandable, often involving reasoning or providing context.  It's more than simply stating a fact.
揉面团 (róu miàntuán) specifically refers to kneading dough.
新教 (xīnjiào) refers to Protestantism, a branch of Christianity.
辞职 (cízhí) specifically means to resign from a job.
结账 (jiézhàng) refers specifically to paying the bill, usually at a restaurant or store.
丢垃圾 (diū lājī) refers specifically to throwing away trash or garbage.
指甲 (zhǐjia) refers specifically to fingernails or toenails.
搭配 (dāpèi) refers to the way things are matched or coordinated, often in terms of clothing, food, or colors.  It implies a sense of harmony or suitability.
强迫症 (qiǎngpòzhèng) refers to Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), a mental health condition.
秘书 (mìshū) refers to a secretary, someone who provides administrative support.
小红书 (xiǎohóngshū) refers to the social media and e-commerce platform RED (also known as Little Red Book).
严格 (yángé) describes something that is strict, rigorous, and demanding, often involving rules or standards.
准确 (zhǔnquè) emphasizes precision and correctness, often involving measurements or information.  It's stronger than simply saying something is right.
老奶奶 (lǎonǎinai) is a term of address for an elderly woman, similar to "grandma" but can be used for any elderly woman, not just one's own grandmother.
恋亚癖 (liàn yà pǐ) refers to the sexual attraction to people of East or Southeast Asian descent and is considered a problematic stereotype.
真诚 (zhēnchéng) emphasizes genuineness, honesty, and sincerity, often in expressing feelings or intentions.
堕落 (duòluò) implies a moral decline or degradation, often involving immoral or corrupt behavior.  It's a strong word suggesting a negative transformation.
打鼾 (dǎhān) refers specifically to snoring.
回头 (huítóu) can mean "turn around" physically, or figuratively mean "later" as in "I'll do it later"  (我回头做 - wǒ huítóu zuò).

A related word is 枪支 (qiāngzhī). 枪支 is more formal, and also more often refers to guns in their capacity as weapons, especially illegal ones.  枪 is more colloquial, and is often used to refer to toy guns, or when talking about the physical object without focusing on its use as a weapon.
A more formal way to say this is 发送邮件 (fāsòng yóujiàn).

There is no difference between the use of 足迹 in Chinese and footprint in English. However, keep in mind that 足迹 can also refer to the places a person has visited. For example, 我走遍了全世界的每一个角落，留下我的足迹 (I have travelled to every corner of the world, leaving my footprints).
For pronunciation, you can add 的 after 发音 to say the pronunciation *of* something, like this:  汉字的发音 (hànzì de fāyīn) - the pronunciation of Chinese characters.
The usage is just like "open the door" in English, there isn't any special usage to keep in mind.
沉浸 is usually followed by 在 or 于.  For example, 他沉浸在游戏中 (He is immersed in the game).  Or, 他沉浸于悲伤中 (He is immersed in grief).

It can refer to physical care, emotional support, or both.  It can also be used to mean "to give consideration to," particularly in a social context, such as "to show consideration for others' feelings."

A related word is "脸色 (liǎnsè)". 表情 refers to the expression formed by one's facial features. On the other hand, 脸色 refers to one's complexion or facial color.

There are many words for "difference" in Chinese. Some of the more common ones are 差异 (chāyì), 区别 (qūbié), and 不同 (bùtóng).  差别 is generally interchangeable with these.  However, sometimes 差别 can be used before a number, when referring to a numerical difference.

This is usually translated as "court". However, specifically, it means "courtroom". A more general word for "court" is 法院 (fǎyuàn).
This word may not be familiar to some native Chinese speakers.
取消 is for cancelling appointments or reservations, not for physical objects. For example, you would not say 取消 a flight. For that, you'd use 撤销 (chèxiāo).
Type of experience, with type de-emphasized.  Usually used in marketing language.  For example, 沉浸式体验 means "immersive experience". Note that the type of experience is put *before* the word 体验.

This word has a broad range of meaning similar to its English translation “role.”  It can refer to one's position in society, or one's part in a play, or even in a more general sense as the capacity someone acts in.

This is a very flexible adverb in Chinese, and is widely used in colloquial speech. It generally conveys the meaning of "almost," "nearly," "more or less," or "approximately."  For example, you might say it before a time if you expect to be a little late.  Or you might use it before a number to say "around" or "give or take" that number.  Note that it can sometimes imply that something is not quite satisfactory.
More formal than other ways of saying to tell, such as 说 (shuō) or 跟…说 (gēn…shuō).
It also means to change/switch seasons (of clothing).
In China, the concept of a "drugstore" is often mixed with that of a cosmetics store. Hence, 药妆店 often includes beauty products.
Means "report", in the sense of "report to the authorities".
Means something happened, or there is something going on. You'd likely use this if you don't want to say what the thing is, or are trying to get someone to guess.

There are two words for funeral: 葬礼 (zànglǐ) and 丧礼 (sānglǐ). The former refers specifically to the burial ceremony, while the latter encompasses all the rituals and ceremonies associated with a funeral.  In most contexts, they're interchangeable.
Can mean survival in the sense of continuing to exist under challenging conditions.  It's a strong word, and may not appropriate in situations where you would just say "live".

Used as a suffix to indicate a type or style of something, similar to "-style," "-type," or "-esque" in English.  It can create words like 中式 (Chinese-style), 西式 (Western-style), 现代式 (modern-style), etc.  The usage is broad, and encompasses everything from styles of food and clothing to architectural design and artistic expression.
This is a sensitive topic in Chinese culture and history, and should be used with caution. It's important to be aware of the historical context and potential emotional impact when using this term.

This word emphasizes that something is objectively true and verifiable, often contrasting it with personal opinions or subjective interpretations. It's sometimes translated as "fact" or "truth," but it carries a stronger connotation of evidence-based reality.
Means "to analyze", and also "analysis".

Colloquial word for octopus, specifically used in Cantonese.  The more standard Mandarin word is 章鱼 (zhāngyú).

Means "to save" in the sense of putting money in a bank or storing something for safekeeping.

When used in the structure "一旦…就…", it means "as soon as" or "the moment that".
A general term referring to dance from Africa.  Be aware that Africa is a continent with a very diverse range of dance traditions.
Can also mean enlightenment or political awakening, carrying a more weighty meaning than simple awareness.
Describes the taste of saltiness.
Usually carries a slightly negative connotation, implying worldliness or materialism, as opposed to spiritual or intellectual pursuits.

Describes physical weakness or frailty due to illness or fatigue.

Can be both positive and negative.  It can mean honest and sincere, but also simple or naive.

可能 (kěnéng) can function as both an adjective and an adverb.<NEWLINE><NEWLINE>As an adjective, it means "possible" and precedes the noun it modifies.  For example:<NEWLINE><NEWLINE>可能的问题 (kěnéng de wèntí): possible problems<NEWLINE><NEWLINE>As an adverb, it means "possibly," "maybe," or "probably" and precedes the verb or adjective it modifies. For example:<NEWLINE><NEWLINE>他可能去 (tā kěnéng qù): He might go.<NEWLINE>这可能很难 (zhè kěnéng hěn nán): This is probably difficult.
There is no difference between the use of 躲开 in Chinese and "dodge" or "get out of the way" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 圈内人 in Chinese and "insider" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 全职 in Chinese and "full-time" in English.
This word is stronger than "and," implying that the second clause adds to the force of the previous one. It can also sometimes be translated as "moreover" or "furthermore."
There is no difference between the use of 休假 in Chinese and "take a vacation" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 第一集 in Chinese and "first episode" in English.

There is no difference between the use of 村子 in Chinese and "village" in English. However, note that while "village" can sometimes refer to a small incorporated town, 村子 strictly refers to a rural settlement with agriculture as the primary activity.
There is no difference between the use of 毛茸茸 in Chinese and "fluffy" or "furry" in English.
搞乱 (gǎo luàn) means "to mess up" or "to make a mess of."  It has a slightly more informal and colloquial connotation compared to  弄乱 (nòng luàn), which also means "to mess up."
There is no difference between the use of 编剧 in Chinese and "screenwriter" in English.
市场 (shìchǎng) has two main meanings: "market" (as in a place to buy goods) and "market" (as in an economic system).  Be sure to consider the context to understand which meaning is intended.
There is no difference between the use of 后排 in Chinese and "back row" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 佛教 in Chinese and "Buddhism" in English.
交通 (jiāotōng) refers to all forms of transportation, including roads, traffic, public transport, and the flow of vehicles.
There is no difference between the use of 求婚 in Chinese and "propose (marriage)" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 出国 in Chinese and "go abroad" in English.
俏皮 (qiàopí) describes someone witty, playful, and slightly mischievous, but in a charming and lighthearted way.
There is no difference between the use of 刑法 in Chinese and "criminal law" in English.

Besides literally meaning "to charge (a battery)", 充电 (chōngdiàn) can also metaphorically mean to recharge oneself or to learn new skills, especially in a professional context. For example, "我要去充电了" can mean "I need to recharge my batteries" or "I need to brush up on my skills."
There is no difference between the use of 友情 in Chinese and "friendship" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 三文鱼 in Chinese and "salmon" in English.
There is no difference between the use of 选票 in Chinese and "ballot" in English.
审核 (shěnhé) means to examine and verify something, usually official documents or applications.  It carries a sense of thorough review and official approval.
缺点 (quēdiǎn) refers to shortcomings, flaws, or weaknesses.  It's similar to 弱点 (ruòdiǎn), but 缺点 is more general, while 弱点 suggests a vulnerability or a weak spot that can be exploited.
There is no difference between the use of 准时 in Chinese and "on time" or "punctual" in English.

麻烦 (máfan) means troublesome or inconvenient. Saying "很麻烦 (hěn máfan)" is a common way to express that something is a hassle. You can also use it when asking someone to do something for you, and want to apologize for the inconvenience, e.g.,  "不好意思，麻烦你了 (bù hǎoyìsi, máfan nǐ le)" which means "Sorry to trouble you."
There is no difference between the use of 香料 in Chinese and "spice" or "seasoning" in English.
为了 (wèile) indicates purpose, meaning "in order to" or "for the sake of."  It is similar to 为了… (wèile…), which emphasizes the intended result or goal.

There is no difference between the use of 初中 in Chinese and "middle school" or "junior high school" in English. Keep in mind, in China 初中 is from grade 7 to 9, unlike other places where it may be from other grades.
纯律 (chúnlǜ) is a term from music theory and likely will not come up in everyday conversations.
骑着 (qízhe) means "riding" or "mounted on," and describes an ongoing state of riding something.
负伤 (fùshāng) means "to be injured" or "to be wounded," typically in the context of combat, accidents, or other physical harm.
公开 (gōngkāi) means "public," "open," or "to make public."  It emphasizes the availability of information or the transparency of an action.

原来 (yuánlái) can have several meanings, including "originally," "formerly," "so," or "it turns out."  The meaning depends on the context.  For example, 原来是这样 (yuánlái shì zhèyàng) means "So that's how it is."
经历 (jīnglì) can be both a noun and a verb.  As a noun, it means "experience." As a verb, it means "to experience" or "to go through."
猥琐 (wěisuǒ) describes someone obscene, vulgar, or morally repulsive. It can also refer to someone who is physically unkempt or shifty in appearance.
高 (gāo) means "tall" or "high," while 矮 (ǎi) means "short" or "low." These are relative terms, so their meaning can depend on the context.
清蒸 (qīngzhēng) is a cooking method that involves steaming food without adding any strong seasonings. It is typically used to preserve the natural flavors of ingredients like fish and vegetables.
读硕士 (dú shuòshì) means "to study for a master's degree" or "to be a master's student."
老总 (lǎozǒng) is a respectful term for a CEO, general manager, or other high-ranking executive.  It's generally used in business settings.
月收入 (yuèshōurù) means "monthly income" or "monthly salary."
柿子 (shìzi) refers to the persimmon fruit.
风景 (fēngjǐng) refers to scenery, landscape, or view. It can encompass both natural landscapes and man-made environments.
装饰品 (zhuāngshìpǐn) refers to decorations, ornaments, or adornments, often used to enhance the appearance of a space or object.
礼堂 (lǐtáng) refers to an auditorium, hall, or assembly hall, typically used for ceremonies, performances, or large gatherings.
断联系 (duàn liánxì) means "to lose contact" or "to break off contact" with someone.
音阶 (yīnjiē) refers to a musical scale, a series of musical notes arranged in ascending or descending order.
谈话 (tánhuà) refers to a conversation, talk, or discussion. It can be formal or informal.
以色列 (Yǐsèliè) is the Chinese name for "Israel."

The most common meaning of 建 is to build or construct (建造 jiànzào).  However, it's also frequently used in Classical Chinese with meanings like "establish" (建立 jiànlì) or "offer advice/suggestions" (提建议 tí jiànyì). Be mindful of the context to discern the intended meaning.  In modern spoken Chinese, 建 is rarely used alone. It's generally found in compound words.

While 大陆 literally translates to "continent," in mainland China, it specifically refers to the mainland area of the People's Republic of China, excluding Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan.  Be aware of this specific political context when encountering this term.  People in Taiwan will likely be offended if you refer to Taiwan as part of 中国大陆.
This term is colloquial and specifically refers to the white lab coat worn by doctors, scientists, and other medical professionals.
This is the standard term for "printer."

降临 carries a formal and somewhat literary tone, often implying the arrival of something significant, grand, or even divine. It's not used for everyday arrivals.  For instance, you wouldn't use 降临 to describe someone arriving at a party.  A more colloquial equivalent might be 到达 (dàodá) or 来 (lái).

While 赌场 technically means any gambling establishment, it often carries a negative connotation due to the illegality of most forms of gambling in mainland China.  Be mindful of the social context when using this term.
This phrase translates to "it depends" or "we'll see." It indicates a decision that will be made based on future circumstances.
打疫苗 is the standard way to say "to get a vaccine."  Note the use of 打 (dǎ - to hit, to fight) in this context.
大方 has two main meanings. It can describe someone as generous (with money), or it can describe someone who is confident and composed in social situations.
兄长 is a more formal and respectful way to say "older brother" than 哥哥 (gēge).
This is the standard term for "mosquito."
This is the standard transliteration for Los Angeles.
This is the standard term for "weather."
This term specifically refers to action movies.

高 and 低 are frequently used with abstract nouns in addition to physical height. For example, 高兴 (gāoxìng – happy) literally means “high spirits,” while 低温 (dīwēn – low temperature) is used to describe cold temperatures.
精神 can mean "spirit," "mind," or "energy." It often appears in phrases like 精神好 (jīngshen hǎo – in good spirits) or 精神病 (jīngshenbìng – mental illness).
This term specifically refers to genetic diseases.
This term refers to computer programming.
矛盾 has two common meanings:  "contradiction" and "conflict."
纠正 implies correcting something that is wrong, often a mistake or a misunderstanding.  It's slightly more formal than 改正 (gǎizhèng).
测评 is a combination of "evaluation" (评估 pínggū) and "testing" (测试 cèshì). It refers to comprehensive evaluations often involving various tests.
This is the standard term for "tuna."
This is the standard term for "lucky."
This is the standard term for "brown."
This term refers to armor, often in a historical or fantasy context.
吊瓶 specifically refers to an IV drip.
相信 means "to believe" or "to trust."
学霸 is slang for a straight-A student, often implying an intense focus on academics.  It carries a somewhat mixed connotation, sometimes implying admiration and sometimes a slight negative judgment.
情绪化 describes someone who is easily swayed by their emotions and therefore acts unpredictably.  It carries a slightly negative connotation.
This is a serious term for "rape."
宣传 often carries a political connotation, implying the dissemination of information, often with a persuasive or propagandistic intent.  It’s more formal and less neutral than 推广 (tuīguǎng).
偶像 refers to an idol, often a celebrity or someone greatly admired.
天黑 simply means "it's dark" or "nightfall."
出轨 refers to infidelity in a romantic relationship.
This is the standard transliteration for Wales.
This term specifically refers to tortoiseshell cats.
付出 emphasizes the effort or cost involved in doing something.  It often implies sacrifice or dedication.
错过 means "to miss" something, often an opportunity.
卡车 is the standard term for "truck."
后果 refers to the consequences or results of an action, often negative.
This term specifically refers to a fixed star.
会计 is the standard term for "accountant" or "accounting."
正式 means "formal" or "official."
This is the standard term for "glacier."
This is the standard term for "wool."
回复 means "to reply" or "to respond."
野外 refers to the wilderness or outdoors.
粤菜 specifically refers to Cantonese cuisine.
This is the standard transliteration for "waltz."
奇妙 describes something wonderful, strange, and fascinating.  It carries a stronger sense of wonder than simply "interesting."

In Chinese, 冰沙 (bīngshā) specifically refers to a blended icy drink or dessert, similar to a smoothie or slushie. It does not typically encompass other forms of shaved ice desserts.  If you want to refer to shaved ice generally, use the term 刨冰 (bàobīng).
When used as a verb, 尊重 (zūnzhòng) is often followed by somebody's opinions, rights, or privacy.  For example, 尊重他人意见 (zūnzhòng tārén yìjiàn) - respect other people's opinions.
基础 (jīchǔ) can be both a noun and an adjective. As an adjective, it means "basic".  As a noun it is more commonly used in the plural form 基础课 (jīchǔ kè), which means basic courses.
This is an abbreviation of 欧洲联盟 (Ōuzhōu Liánméng) - European Union.

预约 (yùyuē) is used for formally reserving something. Use this word for things such as booking a table at a fancy restaurant, scheduling a doctor's appointment, or booking a consultation service. This word is not applicable for booking movie tickets or train tickets.
One cent in US currency. Note that 分 (fēn) is not normally used to refer to non-US cents.  For example, one Canadian cent would be 一加拿大分 (yī Jiānádà fēn).
This word means etymology (the study of word origins).

This word means to settle down. It doesn't always carry the connotation of permanently establishing residence like it does in English, but it does imply living somewhere for an extended, open-ended period.
薄 (báo) can mean thin (as in a thin piece of paper), light (as in light clothing), weak (as in weak tea) and indifferent (as in uncaring of one's family), depending on the context.
痛苦 (tòngkǔ) is generally used for emotional pain or deep suffering. For physical pain, use the verbs 疼 (téng), or the more formal and stronger word 痛 (tòng).
This word means "but rather". It must always be preceded by a negated statement.  If there's no negation in the first clause, just use 但是 (dànshì) or 可是 (kěshì) instead.
This refers to political asylum.
讨论 (tǎolùn) usually implies a more formal and structured discussion, such as a business meeting or academic debate. For casual conversations, use 谈话 (tánhuà), 聊天 (liáotiān) or other colloquial terms.
家养的 (jiāyǎng de) specifically refers to domesticated animals, not plants.
毛毯 (máotǎn) is a thick, often woolen blanket.  A thinner blanket is called a 毯子 (tǎnzi).
下地狱 (xià dìyù) is a serious curse in Chinese.  Use with caution.
碰见 (pèngjiàn) suggests a chance or unexpected encounter. It's more colloquial than 遇到 (yùdào).
后天 (hòutiān) refers to the day after tomorrow.
This is a synonym of 而不是 (érshì) listed above.
This term generally refers to freshwater eels, which are commonly eaten in East Asia. Saltwater eels, like moray eels, have different names.
破产 (pòchǎn) can refer to bankruptcy for both businesses and individuals.
一切 (yīqiè) means "all" or "everything".  It can be somewhat formal.
过塑 (guò sù) refers to laminating.
西方 (xīfāng) in Chinese often implies Western culture or values, not just a geographical location.
This word can be used figuratively to refer to anything useless or unwanted.
政策 (zhèngcè) usually refers to government policy.  For company policies, use 制度 (zhìdù) or 规定 (guīdìng).
合作 (hézuò) emphasizes collaboration and working together. It can be used for both short-term projects and long-term partnerships.
墓碑 (mùbēi) specifically refers to the upright stone marker on a grave.
This word means root word or morpheme.
意识 (yìshí) can mean consciousness, awareness, or even ideology.  The specific meaning depends heavily on context.
白菜 (báicài) is specifically Napa cabbage.
无性恋 (wúxìngliàn) is the term for asexuality.
前些年 (qián xiē nián) means "a few years ago" or "in recent years", but refers to a period of time that concluded several years in the past, not the very recent past.
守旧 (shǒujiù) carries a negative connotation of being resistant to change or progress.  It is a stronger and more negative word than simply "traditional."
谦虚 (qiānxū) is about being modest, especially regarding one's own accomplishments.  It is sometimes seen as a cultural virtue in Chinese society.
残忍 (cánrěn) describes extreme cruelty and ruthlessness. It implies a deliberate infliction of pain or suffering.
眼中 (yǎnzhōng) figuratively means "in one's eyes" or "in one's opinion."

音乐圈 (yīnyuèquān) refers to the music industry or music scene.

The most common way to express percentages such as "20% off" is to say 打八折 (dǎ bā zhé).  A literal translation would be "hit eight fold", where "eight fold" refers to 80% of the original price.  Similarly, "50% off" would be 打五折 (dǎ wǔ zhé), "10% off" would be 打九折 (dǎ jiǔ zhé) and so on.  You can also use the term "折扣" (zhé kòu) to refer to a discount in general.  For example, "There's a discount today" could be said as "今天有折扣" (jīn tiān yǒu zhé kòu).
建议 is typically used for serious suggestions regarding important decisions. For less serious matters, it's better to use other words such as  推荐 (tuī jiàn) which is better translated as "recommend"
Be careful not to confuse this word with 福 (fú) meaning good fortune/happiness.

While 性丑闻 (xìng chǒu wén) is a grammatically correct way to say "sex scandal", it's rarely used in colloquial Chinese.  A more common way to express this would be 性丑闻事件 (xìng chǒu wén shì jiàn), literally "sex scandal incident," or simply 丑闻 (chǒu wén), "scandal," where the context usually implies that it's a sex scandal.

回答 (huídá) is generally more formal than 答 (dá) and implies a more detailed or thoughtful response.
何况 (hékuàng) is used to strengthen a preceding statement by adding a further, even more compelling reason. It can be translated as "much less," "let alone," or "besides."
不送气 (bù sòng qì) is specifically used in phonetics and phonology, not in everyday conversation, to describe sounds not produced by releasing a puff of air, such as the 'p' in 'spin'.

内在美 (nèizài měi) is most accurately translated as 'inner beauty' and cannot be used more generally to talk about physical attractiveness.
愉悦 (yúyuè) implies a higher degree of pleasure than 快乐 (kuàilè) or 高兴 (gāoxìng).
抑郁症 (yìyùzhèng) is clinical depression and should not be confused with words for temporary sadness or low mood.

说实话 (shuō shí huà) is not used simply for general statements that are believed to be true. Rather, it implies some kind of contrast with a previous statement or expectation. It's often used as an introduction to an honest, possibly unpleasant, opinion.

This has a more negative connotation than simply "revealing" something. It often implies exposing something that should have been kept hidden, like a secret or a weakness.
Besides meaning an urge or impulse, 冲动 can also be used as an adjective describing someone as impulsive.
This can be used before a verb or noun. For instance, 优先考虑 (yōuxiān kǎolǜ, give priority to considering) or 优先权 (yōuxiān quán, priority right).

The multiple meanings of 通 can be confusing. Pay close attention to context.  For meanings like "understand" or "expert," look for words like  通晓 (tōngxiǎo - to understand thoroughly) or 通儒 (tōngrú - a learned scholar).
When referring to relieving someone of their duties, 解除 carries a negative connotation, often implying dismissal or termination.

While 留学生 can refer to both students studying abroad and returned students, context is key.  If the context isn't clear, use 海外留学生 (hǎiwài liúxuéshēng) for students studying abroad and 归国留学生 (guīguó liúxuéshēng) for returned students.
This implies going out of one's way to do something.  It's stronger than "specially."
Refers specifically to large-scale venues, typically for sports or performances. Don't use it for small places.
Can refer to both a leak and the action of leaking.  For example,  屋顶漏水了 (wū dǐng lòu shuǐ le - the roof is leaking) and  水管漏水 (shuǐguǎn lòushuǐ - water pipe leakage).
As a verb, 害 is much stronger than simply "to harm." It implies causing serious damage or injury, even death.
This emphasizes keeping something in its current state, often with difficulty.  It's not the same as simply "maintaining" something in good working order.
This refers to a specific time within a season, often associated with a particular activity or event. For example,  播种时节 (bōzhǒng shíjié - sowing season).
Be aware of the measure word 个 for 白天.
This is a more formal term than simply "reading room." It usually refers to a designated space within a library or institution.
This implies a more serious break than just a small crack. It suggests the potential for the object to split apart completely.
躲 emphasizes concealing oneself from something or someone, often out of fear or to avoid being seen. It's different from simply "avoiding" something.
This specifically refers to a murderer or someone who has committed a violent crime. Don't use it for petty criminals.
除了“小学” (xiǎoxué - elementary school) 以外，初等 usually refers to the basic level of something, often in education or skill level.
More formal than 到达 (dàodá). Often used in official announcements or news reports.
Specifically means to register for an exam. Don't confuse it with applying for a job or school, which would be 申请 (shēnqǐng).
This is typically followed by a noun or noun phrase describing a state or condition. For example, 处于危险之中 (chǔyú wēixiǎn zhīzhōng - be in danger).

The meaning of 有没有 changes depending on the word that follows it.  If followed by a noun, it means "Do you have...?" or "Is there...?"  If followed by a verb, it means "Have you ever...?" or "Did you...?"
Figuratively, 渠道 refers to a means or method of obtaining something or achieving a goal, often implying an unofficial or indirect route.
The meaning of "to sprout or bud" is specific to certain plants, like bamboo shoots (竹笋 zhúsǔn).
Usually paired with 另一方面 (lìng yī fāngmiàn - on the other hand).
Relatively formal. In casual conversation, you can use挑 (tiāo) or拣 (jiǎn).
能够 emphasizes ability or capability. It can sometimes be interchangeable with 可以 (kěyǐ), but 可以 focuses more on permission or possibility.
Specifically refers to a wall of a building, not other types of walls like a fence or a city wall.
Refers to the media as a collective entity or industry, including all forms of communication.
Implies a deep respect and admiration, often for someone's achievements or character.  It's stronger than simply "to admire."
Usually followed by a noun or verb phrase, indicating something is beneficial for a particular thing.
A relatively formal word for a cook, especially a professional chef.  A more informal word is厨子 (chúzi).
Specifically refers to an intersection or crossing of roads.
Implies getting something one desires or needs.  It's different from simply "taking" something.
Often used for feedback or responses, especially from the public.
Has two main meanings:  "foot" and "sufficient." Pay attention to context to discern the correct meaning.
In spoken Chinese, often shortened to 下面 (xiàmiàn).
The meaning of "caretaker" is less common than the others, and usually refers to a caretaker government. For example, you might see 过渡政府 (guòdù zhèngfǔ).
A 培训班 is specifically a short-term training class, as opposed to a course that lasts a whole semester, for example.
看管 has the additional nuance of guarding something to prevent it from being stolen, damaged, or misused.  It implies responsibility and a degree of vigilance.

The difference between 但是 and 可是 is subtle and often interchangeable.  但是 is slightly more formal and objective. 可是 conveys a slightly stronger contrast or unexpected turn.  Native speakers often choose based on rhythm and flow of the sentence rather than strict meaning.
当代 specifically refers to the present time, while 现代 (xiàndài) refers to modern times, a period starting at some point in the past.
As a noun referring to the baojia system, it is pronounced with the third tone, whereas in other cases it is pronounced with the fourth tone.
While often translated as "big sister," 大姐 can be used to address any woman slightly older than the speaker as a form of respect or politeness, not just literally an older sister.
前边 (qiánbian) and 前面 (qiánmiàn) are very similar. 前边 emphasizes "the area in front," while 前面 is more directional, pointing towards "the front."  They are often interchangeable.
章 can also refer to a seal or stamp, especially an official one.

地铁站 (dìtiězhàn) is a general term for a subway station.  In specific contexts, it might be more appropriate to use the name of the station itself or a more specific term like 站台 (zhàntái) for the platform.

The meanings of 编 can be broadly split up as follows. When talking about creating some textual content (e.g. writing a book, composing music) use 编. When talking about creating something physical (e.g. braiding hair, weaving a basket), use 编.
This term comes from English. You will also see the more common, shortened form: 模特 (mó tè).
昌盛 describes a state of flourishing and prosperity, often used in a broader context like a nation, economy, or culture.  It's less common to use it for an individual's success.
层面 emphasizes a specific aspect or perspective of a complex issue.  It's not simply a level in a hierarchy, but a distinct dimension of consideration.
干吗 (gànmá) and 为什么 (wèishénme) both mean "why," but 干吗 is more colloquial and implies a slight impatience or surprise.
参赛 specifically refers to participating in a competition, while 参加 (cānjiā) is more general, meaning to participate in any activity.
外观 refers specifically to external appearances. For example, the appearance of a product.
增进 emphasizes the gradual improvement or strengthening of something, like a relationship or understanding.
镇 is a smaller administrative division than a city (市, shì).

Remember that 汉字 refers specifically to the characters themselves, while 中文 (zhōngwén) refers to the Chinese language in a broader sense.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>汉字 refers specifically to Chinese characters, not just any Chinese writing.
名人 is more formal than  明星 (míngxīng), which specifically refers to entertainment celebrities.
市区 specifically refers to the urban area of a city, distinct from suburbs or rural areas.
消除 emphasizes the complete removal of something negative, like doubts or fears, while other words like 去除 (qùchú) focus on simply getting rid of something.
协议 implies a formal, written agreement between parties.
占有 emphasizes the act of possessing or controlling something, possibly even unjustly.  It carries a stronger connotation of ownership than simply having something.

各个 emphasizes individuality and separateness, while 每个 (měige) focuses on every single member of a group.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>各个 emphasizes individuality and separate consideration of each item, while 每个 (měige) simply means "every."
拍摄 focuses on the process of filming or photographing, while 照相 (zhàoxiàng) refers specifically to taking photographs.
星期天 is the most standard way of saying Sunday.
加油 is used to say "add oil" (in a car), and is also commonly used to cheer somebody on, like "Go!" in English.
楼梯 refers to the entire set of stairs, while 台阶 (táijiē) refers to individual steps.
礼 has a broad range of meanings related to social customs, rituals, and proper behavior, extending beyond simply "gift" or "ceremony."
肯 implies willingness or readiness to do something, often after hesitation or reluctance.
上楼 is simply going upstairs, but 登楼 (dēnglóu) implies ascending a tower or a tall building, often for a specific purpose like sightseeing.
生 has a wide range of meanings, from "to be born" to "raw" or "uncooked."  Pay attention to context to determine the correct meaning.
畅通 implies smooth and unimpeded flow, often used in the context of traffic, communication, or processes.
国庆 is used across different Chinese-speaking regions.
道路 refers to roads and paths in a more abstract sense, including metaphorical paths, while  公路 (gōnglù) refers specifically to highways or public roads.
This is the most common and natural way to express "face-to-face."
测试 refers specifically to testing, examination, or evaluation, often more technical or formal than 考试 (kǎoshì) which usually refers to academic exams.
两手 can also mean two different tactics or methods of dealing with some issue.

While 夺 can mean "to seize" or "to rob," it often implies a struggle or competition involved in the taking.  Think of "wresting control" or "snatching victory."  It's more forceful than simply taking something.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Often implies taking something by force or through competition.
Specifically refers to red wine.  Don't confuse it with other alcoholic beverages.  葡萄酒 (pútáojiǔ) is a more general term for wine (made from grapes).
A more formal and less common synonym is 柱 (zhù). 柱子 is more colloquial.
This title is specific to organizations and government departments. It's not a general term for "boss" or "manager."

The many uses of 其 can be confusing.  Pay close attention to context.  Its meaning as a pronoun ("his/her/its/their") is often seen in formal writing.  The meaning of "such," "that" is often paired with a noun, for example, 其他 (qítā) "other."

The grammatical function of 出来 can be tricky.  When it follows a verb, it often indicates the completion of an action or the emergence of a result. For example,  想出来 (xiǎng chūlái) means "to figure something out" (literally, "to think something out").
Primarily means to go on stage (literally or figuratively).  The political meaning ("come into power") is derived from this.
Refers specifically to the long jump (track and field event).
Emphasizes strategic or policy-level decisions. It's more formal and weighty than just deciding what to eat for dinner.
Besides roll call, it can also mean to call someone out (often for praise or criticism), similar to "name-dropping."
Often implies a fundamental change in form, nature, or function.  More profound than simply changing from one state to another.
Encompasses both literature and the arts (performing, visual, etc.). Think "literary and artistic" rather than just literature.

Emphasizes that something applies without exception.  Similar to "all" or "every."<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Highlights inclusivity.  Think "each and every; all; any" rather than simply "all."  Often followed by a statement about things that meet a particular condition.
Specifically means to see a doctor *as a patient*.  医生看病 (yīshēng kànbìng) means "The doctor sees/treats patients."

This term is a set phrase referring to both China and other countries. It’s often used in contexts discussing international relations, cultural exchange, or comparative studies.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Refers to both China and other countries.  Sometimes translated as "Sino-foreign."

Can refer to both the telephone itself and a telephone call. Note the different measure words used: 部 (bù) for the device, and 通 (tōng) for a call.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Can mean both the telephone itself and a phone call.  Use classifiers 部 (bù) for the device and 通 (tōng) for the call.
Implies continuous activity without rest.  Similar to "around the clock."<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Emphasizes continuous activity.  Similar to "around the clock."
Has a wide range of meanings.  Pay close attention to context to determine the appropriate definition.
Specifically refers to a postgraduate student engaged in research.
Can also refer to methamphetamine in slang.
Implies a more complete or thorough separation than just 隔 (gé).
Usually describes something pleasant to hear, like music or a compliment.
Can also be used as slang to mean "awesome."
Can refer to both physical and temporal separation.
樂 has two pronunciations with different meanings.  lè means "happy," while yuè is related to music.  Be mindful of the context.
Refers to a water heater.  For a water boiler to boil water for tea, use 热水瓶 (rèshuǐpíng)
Specifically refers to postage stamps.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Specifically means a postage stamp.
Refers to trends, developments, or movement in a broader sense, not just physical motion.  Think "dynamics."
Emphasizes authenticity and legality, in contrast to pirated copies.
A more colloquial synonym for 快乐 (kuàilè), meaning happy.
Can also refer to something being the "king" or best of its kind.
Can also mean "going the same way" or "of the same kind."
Means "all around" or "on all sides."
Implies effort in obtaining something.  More active than simply receiving.
Often refers to a closed loop or ring.
Has various meanings related to agreements, appointments, and limitations.  Context is crucial.
Describes something new and emerging, often in the context of markets, technologies, or social trends.
Emphasizes that something happened long ago.  More emphatic than simply saying 早 (zǎo) or 很久以前 (hěn jiǔ yǐqián).
Specifically refers to watching a broadcast, typically television.  More formal than simply 看 (kàn).
