Besides its literal meanings, 球 can also be used figuratively to mean "a situation" or "a matter".  For example, "What's the situation?" can be phrased as "什么球?" (shénme qiú?). This usage carries a slightly informal and sometimes frustrated tone.
When used to mean "wield" or "brandish", 舞 often implies a somewhat showy or exaggerated movement, often with a weapon or tool.
While 止 means "stop", it's often used in words that imply a limitation or boundary, like  "为止" (zhǐwéi - up to, until).  Don't confuse it with  "停" (tíng), which implies a temporary halt.

This can often mean "here" in a more general sense, similar to "over here" or "on this side," not just literally "this side."  It can also be used figuratively, referring to a speaker's perspective or situation.
Besides "skin/leather," 皮 can also mean "naughty" or "mischievous," particularly when describing children.  It can also be used to describe something fake or imitation, like "fake leather."
This is specifically artificial intelligence. Don't confuse this with 智慧 (zhìhuì), which refers to the more general concept of "wisdom" or "intelligence".

再生 has several specific meanings in addition to its more general senses of regeneration and revival. It can specifically refer to "recycling", "renewable (resources)", and even the idea of someone being the reincarnation of a previous famous person.
This refers specifically to the president or chairman of an organization or club, not a company president. For that you'd usually use 总裁 (zǒngcái), 董事长 (dǒngshìzhǎng), or simply 总经理 (zǒngjīnglǐ).
This can also be used broadly to refer to any internet user, not just someone you have a personal connection with online.
Refers to a large-scale industry or sector of the economy, not just individual properties or estates.
In a technological context, 更新 often specifically means "to update" software or hardware.
Figuratively, 轨道 refers to a fixed path or trajectory, often implying something that's difficult to deviate from.
美 can be used as a prefix referring to the Americas or the US (美国 měiguó).
办 is a very versatile verb, covering a wide range of meanings related to "doing" or "managing."  It's often used where English might use "handle," "deal with," or "take care of."
This word implies continuous or regular monitoring, often using technical equipment.
This usually refers to a large corporation or conglomerate, not just any group of people.
Specifically refers to celebrating Chinese New Year, not just any new year.
Specifically refers to the captain of a ship or boat, not any other kind of captain.
水泥 specifically refers to cement.
险 can also mean "nearly," as in almost experiencing something dangerous.  For example, "险些摔倒" (xiǎnxiē shuāidǎo) means "nearly fell down."
This is a more formal term for vehicles, often used in official contexts.
园 is often used as a suffix in place names related to gardens, parks, or kindergartens.
单 has many meanings! Besides "single," it can also refer to a list, form, or bill.  It can also mean "thin" or "weak."
This specifically refers to a flower garden.

露 has the specific meaning of showing or revealing something unintentionally or inadvertently.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>This word has a very broad range of meaning. Here's a quick way to look at it:<NEWLINE>- Showing something unintentionally: 露馅儿 (lù xiànr) - "reveal a secret," "let the cat out of the bag"<NEWLINE>- Showing some part of your body: 露脸 (lù liǎn) - "to show one's face"<NEWLINE>- Outdoors: 露营 (lù yíng) - "camping"<NEWLINE>- Dew:  露水 (lùshuǐ) - "dew"
Specifically refers to treating an illness, not just any problem.
This word emphasizes conformity to standards and regulations, often implying official recognition or approval.
Refers specifically to cultivated fields or farmland.

Refers to the amount of heat energy, often used in scientific or nutritional contexts. It's the equivalent of "calories" in discussions about food.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>This word refers specifically to "calories" in a nutritional context, or "heat" in a physics context.
冒 can also mean "to falsely impersonate" or "to feign."<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Has a wide range of meanings, so context is crucial. Pay attention to the verb or noun that follows.
Includes the specified limit, so "10以内" means "up to and including 10".
Implies that the price is not just high, but possibly excessively or unfairly high.
Often used in the context of publishing or releasing something officially, like stamps, books, or currency.
Specifically refers to the army or ground forces.
Can also mean "earlier" or "previously" in time, or "ahead" in a sequence.
贪钱 is stronger than just "thrifty" - it means greedy or avaricious.
This implies a more formal or systematic inquiry, often involving looking up information in a database or official records.
加 is used in many idiomatic expressions and can function as a preposition-like particle.

航空 generally refers to all aspects of air travel and the aviation industry, including aircraft, airlines, and airports.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>Refers to aviation in general, including both aircraft and the industry.
立 can also mean "immediately" or "at once," especially in classical Chinese.
The word 录像 can be both a noun and a verb.  As a verb, it can mean "to record a video," and as a noun, it can mean "video recording."  Note the measure word is 盘 (pán).
When 稳 is used to mean "stable" (e.g., describing an object), its opposite is "unstable" (不稳). When 稳 means "calm and collected," the opposite is usually 急 (jí) - "hurried, anxious."
洋 has several seemingly unrelated meanings.  Learners should be careful to distinguish between "ocean" (海洋), "foreign" (西洋 - Western;東洋 - Eastern), and "vast/multitudinous" (汪洋 - vast ocean).
Besides meaning "fast food," 快餐 can also mean "snack" or "quick meal," particularly something simple eaten quickly.
什么样 is used to ask about the characteristics or qualities of something.  For example, "What kind of person is he?" (他是什么样的人？).
While 启事 means "notice" or "announcement," it specifically refers to written announcements, often posted publicly.
赖 has many meanings, including "to depend on," "bad," "to renege," and even the name of the messaging app LINE in Taiwan.  Be aware of the context to understand the correct meaning.
吞 implies swallowing something whole, without chewing, often with difficulty.
A simple word, but remember the word order:  "the day before yesterday," not "yesterday before day."
书桌 specifically refers to a desk used for writing or studying, not just any table.
细菌 is the general term for "bacteria."
移 focuses on the movement of something from one place to another, often implying a change of position or location.
党 generally refers to a political party but can also mean other organized groups.
爽 has two main sets of meanings:  one related to clarity and openness (clear weather, frank personality), and another related to pleasant physical sensations (feeling refreshed, invigorated).
光辉 describes a brilliant, shining light, often metaphorically used for glory or magnificence.
作出 emphasizes the process of creating or producing something, often a decision, judgment, or creative work.
好看 means both "good-looking" and "good" in the sense of enjoyable (for a movie, book, etc.). It can also mean "embarrassed" or "humiliated," which stems from losing face.
产量 specifically refers to the amount of something produced, often in an industrial or agricultural context.
挖 describes digging or excavating, often implying removing something from the ground.
总经理 usually refers to the highest-ranking executive in a company, equivalent to CEO or President.
祖父 specifically means paternal grandfather.  Maternal grandfather is 外祖父 (wàizǔfù).
档案 refers to a collection of documents or records, often official or historical.
拿出 describes the action of taking something out, often to present or use it.
如同 is a more formal way of saying "like" or "as."
抬头 has the literal meaning of "raise one's head" and also means "gain ground" or "look up."  It also appears on checks and forms where you write the account name.
城乡 refers to both urban and rural areas considered together.
待会儿 means "in a little while" or "later," indicating a short time in the future.
优质 specifically refers to high or excellent quality.
周年 celebrates a full year from a significant event, like an anniversary.
出于 indicates the source or reason for something, often translated as "out of," "due to," or "stemming from."
数目 refers to a quantity or amount, often of countable items or money.
专利 refers to a patent, the exclusive right granted for an invention.
人权 refers to human rights.
大规模 signifies something large-scale or extensive.
摇头 means "to shake one's head," often indicating disagreement or disapproval.
接下来 indicates what happens next in a sequence of events.  It can also mean "to accept" or "to take," but this meaning is less common.
听取 implies listening attentively to something, often a report, opinion, or suggestion.
南方 generally refers to the southern part of a region, and in China specifically, it usually means the areas south of the Yangtze River.
田径 refers specifically to track and field athletics.
多云 is the meteorological term for "cloudy."

column1: 相机 (at the opportune moment; as the circumstances allow)
column2: This meaning is somewhat literary.  A more common way to express this is 伺机 (sìjī) or 见机行事 (jiànjī xíngshì).
This meaning is less common. More frequently, "recurrence" is expressed using words like 复发 (fùfā) or 重犯 (chóngfàn), depending on the context.
While 创新 can be used as a verb, it's more commonly used as a noun.  As a verb, "to innovate" is often expressed as 进行创新 (jìnxíng chuàngxīn) or 开展创新 (kāizhǎn chuàngxīn).

column1: 尖 (the best of sth; the cream of the crop)
column2: In this context, 尖 is usually used with the word "儿" (jiānr). For example,  尖儿货 (jiānr huò) means "top-quality goods."  Another way to express "the best of sth" is  精华 (jīnghuá) or  最优秀的 (zuì yōuxiù de).
This is a formal word.  A more colloquial way to say "total" is  一共 (yígòng) or  总共 (zǒnggòng).

column1: 客气 (polite; courteous; modest; polite; courteous; formal; modest)
column2: The meaning of "modest" for 客气 usually arises in the context of declining something offered, often followed by a phrase like  不用 (búyòng) or  别 (bié).  For example, you might say  "您太客气了，不用了" (nín tài kèqì le, búyòng le) - "You're too kind, there's no need."
A similar word is 充满 (chōngmǎn), but 布满 emphasizes a surface being covered, while 充满 emphasizes a space being filled.
This is a more formal and written way of saying "recently."  A more common and spoken way to say this is  最近 (zuìjìn).
This refers specifically to a structured outline or framework of a larger work, not just any summary.  A more general word for "summary" would be 摘要 (zhāiyào) or  概括 (gàikuò).
This emphasizes a dry cold.  If you want to describe a damp cold, you might use  阴冷 (yīnlěng).

While this can refer to a young person, it often carries a connotation of youthful vigor and idealism, often associated with a specific age range (typically late teens to early thirties).  A more neutral term for "young person" is  年轻人 (niánqīngrén).
This word is often used figuratively to describe someone's potential or inherent qualities, sometimes with negative connotations.  For example,  坏胚子 (huài péizi) means "bad egg" or "troublemaker."
The meaning of "house on a cliff" refers to the radical itself, not the standalone character.
The "儿" (er) suffix makes this word specifically Beijing dialect. The standard way to say "have free time" is simply 有空 (yǒukòng).
This is a more formal way of saying "live."  A more colloquial equivalent is  住 (zhù).
This can also imply summarizing a complex issue into a simple statement.
This can also be used as a noun, meaning "beforehand" or "earlier."
This emphasizes something being specifically chosen or designated, not just any particular thing.  特定 implies a deliberate selection or identification.
This usage is outdated and rarely used today.  It might be found in older literature, but it's not common in modern conversation.  Use  有趣 (yǒuqù) or  好玩儿 (hǎowánr) instead.
These meanings of 应 often imply a responsibility or obligation.  It's stronger than a simple "should" and closer to "must" or "shall."
This can sometimes imply a mistake in perception or judgment.
The meanings related to "appear" or "look" are less common.  形 primarily refers to form or shape.
These are places known for their beauty or historical significance, not just any scenic spot.
While the measure word is 个, it can also be measured with 颗 (kē) in Taiwan.
This usage is generally used in the passive voice, meaning "to be made anxious" by something, expressed as  被…急坏了 (bèi... jí huài le) or similar constructions.
The measure word is 个, but using 家 (jiā) after a country name is more natural e.g. 英国 (yīngguó) England, becomes 英国一家公司  a British Company, or 法国一家餐馆 a French restaurant.
It's often paired with 才 (cái) to emphasize the necessary condition.
While 瓶 can be used for liquids, it specifically refers to the container.  For the liquid itself, other classifiers might be more appropriate, depending on the context.
In philosophical contexts, it can also mean "subject" as opposed to "object."
This implies charitable giving.  For other types of contributions, use  贡献 (gòngxiàn).
This implies a more formal accompaniment, often for official purposes.  A more casual way to say "accompany" is  跟…一起 (gēn... yīqǐ) or  和…一起 (hé... yīqǐ).
This can also be used figuratively to describe limited abilities or resources.
This can also refer to a specific version or release of software or a publication.
More formal than 建立, and usually used for abstract things, such as committees, funds, etc.
Can be used as a verb, meaning "to increase production". Can also be used as an adjective, meaning "increased production".
When used as a measure word, it is pronounced chuáng, otherwise it's pronounced chuáng.
This word can be used generally to refer to any contestant. It does *not* mean "player".  A more general word for "player" is 玩家 (wánjiā).

The word 不良 can be translated as "bad," "harmful," or "unhealthy," but it carries a specific connotation of being *not good* or *not up to standard*. It often describes something that is deficient, flawed, or has negative consequences.  For example, 不良行为 (bùliáng xíngwéi) translates to "bad behavior" or "misconduct," implying actions that deviate from accepted norms or have harmful effects.  Similarly, 不良反应 (bùliáng fǎnyìng) refers to "adverse reactions," such as to a medication. It suggests a negative response or unintended consequence.  Therefore, while 不良 can encompass a sense of "badness," it often emphasizes a lack of quality, suitability, or a deviation from a desired standard.
Can be any kind of port, e.g. seaport, airport, river port, etc.
This suffix means "person" or "people involved in". For example, "商界人士" (shāngjiè rénshì) means "business people".
This is more formal than 取消 (qǔxiāo).
This literally translates to "produced domestically". It has a similar usage to "made in \[country]" in English.

As a verb, this word means to check out (of a hotel). However, when it appears as part of another word, it takes on other meanings such as "bear; form; knit; knot; (of a plant) to produce (fruit or seeds); sturdy; bond; to tie; to bind.
In the context of games, means to score points. But it can also mean more generally "to gain marks" (in a test).
Relates to the outward appearance or arrangement of something.
This refers to any film actor or actress. 明星球星 (míngxīng) is more general.
There is no difference between 番茄 (fānqié) and 西红柿 (xīhóngshì).
This word refers to rumors/hearsay which are *negative*, e.g. relating to scandals.
Only used for physical resistance, like to infection. If you mean something more abstract, you should use 反抗 (fǎnkàng).
Usually used for games, not real life.
This refers to comics generally, and not specifically Japanese manga. If you specifically mean "manga", then you should say 日本漫画.
Refers to restrictions *on freedom*, either physical (e.g. being tied up) or abstract (e.g. rules).
This means *approximately*. Similar to 左右.
This is the traditional form of 抓 (zhuā).
Relates to creating something *new* out of multiple components. It isn't simply "putting things together".
This literally means "old friend". However, it is also internet slang for "period" (menstruation).
This refers to *both* teachers and students.
The 的 is often omitted, especially in speech. In this case it is simply pronounced " huà".
The meaning is closer to "flushed" rather than simply "very red".
This means "chest" in general, and not specifically breast. For breast you should use 乳房 (rǔfáng).
This means examination for the purpose of *censorship*.
This indicates a contrast is coming up, usually indicated with 但是, 可是, or 还是.
Used for exams/tests. Can also just generally refer to the midpoint of a period of time.
Refers to taking a taxi *in town*, and does not include hitching a lift. For a lift, you should use 搭便车 (dābiànchē).
Refers to oneself.  本 is a prefix showing emphasis on ownership.
Refers to the physical radiator unit itself. 暖气 (nuǎnqì) refers to the heating system generally.
Refers to electric vehicles generally, including scooters, bikes, cars, etc. If you mean electric car, you should use 电动汽车 (diàndòng qìchē).
More formal than 打电话 (dǎ diànhuà).
Abbreviation of 高速公路 (gāosù gōnglù).
Can only be used with physical amounts, not abstract amounts.
More formal than 提高 (tígāo), and usually used for abstract things such as prices.
Refers to the *system* of laws, rather than laws themselves. 法律 (fǎlǜ) refers to the laws themselves.
Can also refer to *city walls*. Also, don't forget it has several different measure words.
Slang meaning of prostitute is outdated.
When it means "size", it can be used as an adjective. For example, 大小城市 (dàxiǎo chéngshì) means "cities of all sizes".
Can also refer to a specific product within a larger product line.
自 can act as a prefix to words to express the meaning of "-self", such as 自我 (zìwǒ, oneself) and 自动 (zìdòng, automatic).

A related word is 应聘 (yìngpìn), which means "to apply for a job."  求职 is more general and refers to the overall process of looking for work, while 应聘 specifically refers to applying for a particular position.

A related word is 争端 (zhēngduān), which often refers to larger-scale disputes, often between organizations or countries. 纠纷, on the other hand, is often used for more personal or smaller-scale disagreements.

Can also refer to one's social standing or place in a hierarchy, or to the status one aspires to. In marketing, 定位 refers to the process of establishing a product's or brand's unique position in the market.
This can also mean "what the people want" rather than "what they think." It is usually used in a political or social context.
A more formal term than 家人 (jiārén), and may have legal implications. For example, in legal documents, 亲属 is the correct word to use, whereas 家人 would be inappropriate.
Figuratively, it can mean "to join in" or "to get involved," often carrying a slightly negative connotation of opportunism.
More formal than 以前 (yǐqián).
Has a slightly broader usage than "those." It can also mean "such" or "that kind of" when describing abstract concepts or qualities.
In a technical context, it can mean "proprietary" or "independently developed."
Can be used for abstract things like ideas, technology, or management practices, as well as concrete things like products or species.
More formal than 工资 (gōngzī).
More formal than 可以吗 (kěyǐ ma)?
In the context of waiting, 稍等 (shāo děng) is a more polite way to say "wait a moment" than 等一下 (děng yīxià).
This word has more of a scientific or formal tone.
It can refer to the manner of expressing something, as opposed to the content of what is being expressed.
More formal than 这 (zhè).
When describing people, it can carry a sense of liveliness and energy.
More formal and legalistic than 根据 (gēnjù). It often refers to formal documents or legal principles.
Refers to a close, often long-standing friendship. It has connotations of intimacy and shared history.
It has a wide semantic range. It can translate to “director,” “manager,” “supervisor,” or “person in charge.” Its specific meaning is determined by context.
Can also refer to other sandwich-like foods, like burgers.
While primarily used for vocal concerts, it can also refer to concerts featuring other musical instruments, if vocals are a significant part of the performance.
Implies a precise correlation or a perfect fit between two things. It can emphasize the right time, the right person, or the right circumstances.
Can refer to non-monetary costs like time and effort, particularly in metaphorical uses.
Often used for adding something to an existing quantity or collection. It also commonly refers to having a child.
When referring to discrepancies, it often implies a significant difference or inconsistency, potentially causing confusion or problems.
More formal and scientific than 月亮 (yuèliang).
In colloquial use, can sometimes refer to going to the toilet (大号, dàhào).
Can be followed by a noun, verb, or clause. It indicates exclusion or exception.
A poetic and somewhat archaic term.
Not just about saving energy, but also about using it efficiently.
Focuses on being admitted to an educational institution.
Can also have a metaphorical meaning, referring to a process or a period.
Refers specifically to the English language.
Refers to the first three days of a specific period.
Colloquial and often used for children's drawings.
This word can be used as a sentence-final particle, indicating conjecture.
A related word is 长期 (chángqí), which means long-term.
A related word is 精致 (jīngzhì), which is very similar, but perhaps even more refined and exquisite than 精美.
This word consists of the characters 伤 (shāng), meaning injury, and 员 (yuán), meaning member or personnel. Together, they form the word for "wounded person".

实行 (shíxíng) and 执行 (zhíxíng) both mean "to implement" or "to carry out," but they have slightly different connotations. 实行 emphasizes the actual implementation or putting a plan into effect, often referring to policies, systems, or reforms. 执行 focuses on the process of carrying out a task, order, or law. 执行 often implies a more specific and concrete action.
This word is the literary equivalent of 眼泪 (yǎnlèi), the more common word for "tear."  It's often used in poetry or song lyrics.
Note that this only refers to running, and not to other long-distance races like swimming, or cycling.
The meaning and usage are pretty much identical to 尽量 (jìnliàng).
多数 (duōshù) and 大多数 (dàduōshù) both mean "majority," but 大多数 emphasizes an even larger proportion.  Think of 多数 as "majority" and 大多数 as "vast majority."
When used as an adverb, 大大 (dàdà) means "greatly" or "enormously." It's often used in a positive context to emphasize a significant increase or improvement.

观看 (guānkàn) and 看 (kàn) both mean "to watch" or "to see."  观看 is more formal and implies a more attentive or purposeful viewing, such as watching a performance or ceremony. 看 is more general and can be used in any context.
请问 (qǐngwèn) is a polite way to start a question, similar to "Excuse me, may I ask...?"  It's essential for asking strangers for information or help.
This word can also be used metaphorically to refer to a pleasant or welcoming attitude.
夜里 (yèli) and 晚上 (wǎnshang) both refer to "nighttime."  夜里 specifically emphasizes the period from midnight to dawn, while 晚上 is a more general term for the evening or night.
This term is sometimes shortened to just 高科 (gāokē).
信用 (xìnyòng) encompasses both "credit" in the financial sense and "trustworthiness" in a more general sense.
This phrase is used to ask whether something is possible or permissible. It's more direct than asking with only 能 (néng) and implies a degree of uncertainty or doubt.
伤 can be used as a verb or a noun. As a verb, it means "to hurt," "to injure," or "to wound." As a noun, it means "injury," "wound," or "harm."

气 (qì) has many meanings, including "air," "gas," "breath," "smell," "weather," and "vital energy" (as in qigong). It's also used to express anger or annoyance.  Pay close attention to context to determine the intended meaning.
矿 (kuàng) can refer to either the mine itself or the ore extracted from it.
This is short for 毫米 (háomǐ).
Remember that 乳 (rǔ) can be used to talk about breasts, especially in a medical context.
词 (cí) can refer to a single word, a phrase, a statement, speech, or even a specific form of classical Chinese poetry.  The context is crucial for understanding its intended meaning.
闪 (shǎn) has many meanings, including "dodge," "flash," "sparkle," and "sprain."  It can also be used in the online slang sense of being overly saccharine or romantic.
平原 (píngyuán) is related to the word 平地 (píngdì), flat land.
帅哥 (shuàigē) is commonly used to address or refer to attractive men.  It's often translated as "handsome guy."
A related word is 设备 (shèbèi), which means equipment. Both words can be used when talking about scientific apparatus.
大厅 (dàtīng) specifically refers to a large hall or lobby, often in a public building like a hotel or theater.  It's distinct from a regular room or hallway.
共享 (gòngxiǎng) emphasizes the joint or shared nature of an activity or resource.  It's often used in the context of shared economies, like bike-sharing or ridesharing.
吸管 (xīguǎn) specifically refers to drinking straws.
写字楼 (xiězìlóu) refers specifically to office buildings. It carries the connotation of white-collar work and modern business environments.
金牌 (jīnpái) specifically means "gold medal" as in an award for achievement.
线索 (xiànsuǒ) refers to a clue or a lead, often in the context of solving a mystery or investigation.
浮 (fú) has many meanings related to floating, both literally and figuratively.  It can also mean superficial, unstable, or excessive.

入门 (rù mén) means both "entrance door" and "introduction to a subject." It's also a verb meaning "to learn the basics of a subject" or "to enter a door." Pay close attention to context for the intended meaning.
改造 (gǎizào) means to transform or reform, often implying significant improvement or change.  It's often used in the context of societal or political reform.
钢琴 (gāngqín) is short for 钢琴 (gāngqín).
博客 (bókè) is a transliteration of the word "blog."
此时 (cǐshí) means "at this moment" or "now," emphasizing the specific point in time. It's more formal and literary than 現在 (xiànzài).
The character 鼓 (gǔ) has various meanings, including "drum" (the instrument), to beat a drum, to rouse or encourage, and to swell or bulge.  Context is essential for understanding its specific usage.

治 (zhì) can mean "to govern" or "to cure/treat".  Be careful not to confuse it with 制 (zhì) which means "to make" or "system".  Although they sound the same, they have completely different meanings and uses.

While 波浪 (bōlàng) generally refers to waves, it's often used poetically or figuratively to describe undulating or wavy things, like hair or a rolling landscape.  It carries a more evocative sense than just the physical waves in water.

The key difference between 查 (chá) and other verbs for "to look for" is that 查 specifically implies an investigation, an official inquiry or a systematic search, often to uncover hidden information or solve a problem. It's not just casually looking for your keys, it's more like a detective investigating a case or an auditor examining financial records.

科技 is a shortened form of 科学技术 (kēxué jìshù), referring to science and technology as a unified concept.<NEWLINE>--------<NEWLINE>科技 is a very common and important word, often used in discussions about technological advancements, scientific discoveries, and societal progress driven by these developments. It emphasizes the interconnectedness of science and technology.
定 (dìng) has many meanings, so pay close attention to context. As a verb, it can mean "to decide," "to fix," or "to book/order." As an adjective, it means "calm" or "stable."

没错 (méi cuò) is a common way to express agreement or affirmation. It can be translated as "that's right," "exactly," or "you're correct."  It's an informal expression frequently used in spoken Chinese.
剩下 describes something that remains after a portion has been used, consumed, or taken away.  It emphasizes what is left over or remaining, highlighting the portion that hasn't been affected or used.
部 (bù) has a wide range of meanings. As a noun, it can refer to a government ministry or department, a section or part of something, or a classifier for literary works, films, and machines.
乐曲 specifically refers to a musical composition or piece of music, not just any sound or melody.  It implies a structured and organized musical work, often with distinct parts or movements.
胡子 generally refers to facial hair, including both beards and mustaches.  It can also be used colloquially to refer to bandits, reflecting historical stereotypes.
很难说 is a common way to express uncertainty or indecisiveness. It means "it's hard to say" and is often used when the outcome of a situation is unclear or unpredictable.
挨打 implies receiving a beating or being subjected to physical violence. It emphasizes the passive nature of being hit or attacked, highlighting the experience of receiving blows.
网页 refers to a single page of a website. It's a fundamental unit of online content, distinct from a website as a whole, which may comprise multiple web pages.
吃饭 is a common and versatile phrase, meaning "to eat" or "to have a meal." It can also refer to making a living, especially in informal contexts.
农产品 refers specifically to agricultural products, encompassing crops, livestock, and other goods produced through farming. It's often used in discussions of agriculture, food production, and trade.
利 (lì) has multiple meanings, including "sharp," "favorable," "advantage," "benefit," "profit," and "interest." Its specific meaning depends heavily on the context.
全国 means "nationwide" or "the entire country." It emphasizes the scope of something extending across the whole nation, encompassing all regions and areas.
上课 means "to attend class" or "to have a class." It refers to the act of participating in a lesson or lecture, whether as a student or teacher.
消防 refers to firefighting and fire control, encompassing all activities related to preventing, extinguishing, and mitigating the effects of fires.
来源 refers to the source or origin of something, such as information, resources, or materials. It highlights the point or place from which something originates or derives.
家园 refers to one's home or homeland, carrying a sense of belonging and connection to a particular place. It often evokes feelings of nostalgia and attachment.
母鸡 means "hen," referring to a female chicken, particularly one kept for egg production. It's also humorous slang mimicking Cantonese for "don't know."
托 (tuō) has various meanings, including "to support from under," "to set off," "to entrust," "to plead," and "to rely." Pay close attention to context to discern the correct meaning.
课题 refers to a topic, task, problem, or issue that is the subject of research, study, or discussion. It represents a specific area of inquiry or focus.
回顾 means "to review" or "to look back," often at past events or experiences. It implies a reflective examination of something that has already happened.
嘴巴 means "mouth," and can also refer to a slap in the face depending on the context. It is often used colloquially and can have various idiomatic expressions associated with it.
美容 refers to beauty and cosmetology, encompassing practices and treatments aimed at improving one's appearance. It often involves cosmetics, skincare, and other beauty-related products or services.
卫星 means "satellite," referring to an object that orbits a planet or other celestial body. It's often used in discussions of space exploration, telecommunications, and scientific observation.
见到 means "to see" or "to meet," implying visual contact or encountering someone. It indicates the act of perceiving something or someone with one's eyes.
煤 simply means "coal," referring to the black or brownish-black sedimentary rock used as a fuel source. It's often used in discussions of energy, industry, and environmental issues.
大胆 means "bold" or "daring," describing someone who is courageous, adventurous, and willing to take risks. It can also carry a negative connotation, suggesting recklessness or audacity.

高考 refers to the college entrance examination, a crucial exam for students seeking admission to higher education institutions. It's a high-stakes exam that plays a significant role in Chinese education.
无边 means "boundless" or "without boundary," describing something that is vast, limitless, and without edges or limits. It often conveys a sense of immensity or vastness.
外面 means "outside," referring to the external world beyond a particular space or area. It can also refer to the outward appearance or surface of something.
放到 means "to put to" or "to put into," implying the action of placing something in a specific location or container. It indicates the movement of an object to a designated place.
碰到 means "to run into" or "to bump into," both literally and figuratively.  It can refer to physically encountering someone or something unexpectedly, or to encountering a problem or difficulty.
老家 refers to one's hometown or ancestral home, often carrying a strong sense of nostalgia and connection to one's roots. It represents the place where one's family originated or where one grew up.
首脑 refers to a head or leader, typically of a government, organization, or group. It can also refer to a summit meeting between leaders of different countries or organizations.
神 has multiple meanings, including "god," "deity," "spirit," "expression," and "look." It can also mean "supernatural," "magical," or "awesome" depending on the context.
A more formal way to say 频繁 is often 屡次 (lǚcì). Note that 屡次 has a more negative connotation, implying that something bad is happening repeatedly.
Can be used as an adjective to describe a stuffy nose, like 鼻子堵了 (bízi dǔ le).
There is no difference between the usage of 晚 in Chinese and "evening" in English.
联手 can also refer to two companies collaborating on a project, and does not necessarily imply any deeper or more permanent kind of partnership.

成交 is typically used for successful business deals or transactions.  It emphasizes the finalization of the agreement, the closing of the deal, or when a price is agreed upon.<NEWLINE>Other words can be used to describe agreements in different situations. For reaching a consensus or agreement in opinions or plans, you would use 达成协议 (dáchéng xiéyì) or 达成一致 (dáchéng yīzhì).  For completing a project or task, 完成 (wánchéng) would be appropriate.
When 市 means "market," it does *not* take the measure word 个.  It would be correct to say, e.g.,  菜市 (càishì) or 超市 (chāoshì).  But it would be incorrect to say 一个菜市.
天下 is usually used as part of a larger idiom, such as 天下第一 (tiānxià dìyī).
当前 is more formal than 现在 (xiànzài).
手 is also used as part of the slang, referring to someone new to a particular hobby or activity. For instance, 摄影新手 (shèyǐng xīnshǒu) translates to "photography newbie."
高潮 has a sexual connotation. Use 顶峰 (dǐngfēng) if that is not what you intend to mean.
There is no difference between the usage of 中期 in Chinese and "mid-term" in English.
A more formal way to say 平手 is 打成平手 (dǎ chéng píngshǒu).

听到 emphasizes the successful reception of a sound by the listener, confirming they have heard something. 听见 (tīngjiàn) suggests a more passive reception of sound, merely becoming aware of a sound without necessarily making a conscious effort to listen.
Use this when something touches you at an emotional level. For being impressed by a skill or talent, use 佩服 (pèifú).

神情 describes the overall appearance and demeanor of a person, encompassing both facial expressions and body language.  It can be associated with emotions.  表情 (biǎoqíng) refers specifically to facial expressions.
餐 can only be used as a noun or measure word. Do not use it as a verb.
早 can also be used sarcastically to mean something like "serves you right".

脆 has various meanings depending on the context. For food, it means "crispy" or "crunchy." For voices, it means "clear" or "crisp." For actions or decisions, it describes something done quickly and decisively.
This usually implies a serious campaign by the authorities to clean something up.
单一 does not necessarily have a negative connotation. It simply means something is not diverse.
No difference from English "patriotic."

As a verb, there are some usage differences compared with English “show.” When you show something that was previously hidden, you can indeed use 显 or 显示. However, for demonstrations or presentations where you actively show something to someone (such as showing a product or demonstrating a skill), you should use 展示 (zhǎnshì), 演示 (yǎnshì), or similar verbs.
既 is usually used together with 又 (yòu). It does not function alone.

专题 (zhuāntí) and 特辑 (tèjí) are used differently. 专题 usually refers to a specific topic that may appear in various formats, such as a lecture, a book, or a TV program segment. 特辑 is exclusively used for a special program or publication dedicated to a particular topic.
No difference in usage from English "empire."
金额 is used for formal financial documents or contexts. In everyday life, use 钱 (qián).

含 (hán) and 包含 (bāohán) differ in the scope of inclusion. 含 refers to something contained directly within, while 包含 includes a broader sense of containing or encompassing, possibly indirect inclusion.
No usage differences with English.
No usage differences with English.
壮观 is usually reserved for impressive natural sights or very large things.
推进 is used when a project is driven forward effectively and decisively.  推动 (tuīdòng) refers to a more gradual and consistent push, like promoting social progress.
给予 (jǐyǔ) is more formal than 给 (gěi).

依旧 (yījiù) implies the continuation of a previous state, suggesting that something remains unchanged despite changes in the surroundings. 仍然 (réngrán) also indicates the unchanging nature of something, but with less emphasis on the contrast with previous circumstances.
Usually only women and children 撒娇.
No usage differences with English.
踏 can also mean to visit or to investigate, such as 实地踏查 (shídì tàchá) means "field visit" or "on-the-spot investigation".
No usage differences with English.

想起 describes the spontaneous retrieval of memories or thoughts. It's the act of something suddenly coming to mind.  想起来 describes a more deliberate effort to retrieve a memory or piece of information, especially when prompted by a question, clue, or situation.
南北 is frequently used to refer to different regions of China, encompassing both geographical and cultural differences, sometimes contrasting northern and southern cuisine.
珠宝 is a general term covering both precious stones and jewelry made from them.  首饰 (shǒushì) refers specifically to jewelry or ornaments, regardless of what materials they are made from.

The word 闲 (xián) can be used as an adjective to describe someone who is not busy or something that is unoccupied. It can also be used as a verb, meaning "to stay idle."  As a noun, it refers to leisure time. Be aware of the multiple meanings and pay attention to the context to determine the correct interpretation.  Finally, note the different tone from 娴 (xián), which means "skilled; practiced; refined."
下 can also mean "next" in contexts like next month (下月 - xià yuè) or next year (明年 - míngnián).
一次性 can be used before a noun, like "一次性筷子" (disposable chopsticks).  It can also be used by itself like "这是不是一次性的?" (Is this disposable?)

This word emphasizes the process of searching and identifying something specific among other things. Consider the difference with 找到 (zhǎodào) which simply means "to find."  For example, you might use 找出 when talking about identifying the cause of a problem or picking out a particular item from a group.
Be sure not to confuse this with "上" and "来" separately, which have completely different meanings.
While 赞助 can mean both "sponsor" and "to sponsor," it typically implies financial support. If you are talking about other forms of support, other words might be more appropriate.
旅客 refers to any traveler, but it more specifically indicates someone taking public transport.  A more colloquial word for traveller is simply 旅行者.
The word 乘 (chéng) means to ride in or on a vehicle. 乘车 is more specific than 坐车 (zuòchē) and is normally used for public transportation.
键 (jiàn) can refer to both physical keys (like on a keyboard) and metaphorical keys (like a key to success). Be aware of this distinction in different contexts.
这么 is used before adjectives or adverbs, while 这样 is used before verbs.  For example:<NEWLINE><NEWLINE>这么漂亮 (zhème piàoliang): so beautiful<NEWLINE>这样走 (zhèyàng zǒu): walk this way
This is a very general term and could apply to any type of vehicle. It’s different from 泊车, which specifically means parking at a designated place, normally where someone helps you to park.
终身 (zhōngshēn) carries a sense of permanence or lasting commitment.  It’s frequently used in contexts related to lifelong learning, career pursuits, or marriage.
This is more formal than just making a mistake. It usually means a significant mistake, in a job or a game etc.

管道 (guǎndào) can refer to both physical pipes and abstract channels of information or communication. Pay attention to the context to discern the intended meaning.  Also, be sure to distinguish it from 隧道 (suìdào), which means "tunnel."
This term is often used in education and skill-based activities to describe the level of challenge.
Despite appearing to mean "not often", 不时 actually means "frequently" or "often".  It can also mean "occasionally" or "from time to time".
This word can be used both as a noun and a verb.
变换 (biànhuàn) implies a more significant or noticeable change than simply changing something slightly. It often refers to a transformation or alteration in form, appearance, or nature.
This word is only used for car and motor vehicle exhibitions.
Note the measure word for 松树 is 棵 (kē), just like other trees.
This can refer to both judges in law and referees in sports. The context will make the meaning clear.
This word is only used for academics, referring to end of semester or term.
While both 洗衣粉 and 洗衣液 are used for washing clothes, 洗衣粉 is a powder and 洗衣液 is a liquid.

鲜 (xiān) has several meanings, including "fresh," "bright (color)," "delicious," and "rare."  The specific meaning depends on the context. Also, note the related character 鲜 (xiǎn), which means "few; rare."
收集 implies a systematic and purposeful gathering, often of things of a particular kind.  It is different from simply gathering or collecting things randomly.
如一 (rúyī) is often used with the words始終 (shǐzhōng, "from beginning to end; always; all along"), such as 始终如一 meaning "consistent from beginning to end."
This describes areas bordering the sea, typically with a focus on the coastline and nearby regions.
While this can encompass both cities and towns, it often leans more towards smaller urban areas or settlements that are not as large or developed as major cities.
厂商 (chǎngshāng) refers specifically to companies or businesses that manufacture products. It is distinct from general terms for businesses or companies.
便条 (biàntiáo) is usually a short, informal note, often handwritten.  It’s different from a formal letter or a longer memo.
This refers to the dark hours of the night.
This is typically followed by "but also" (而且 - érqiě), similar to "not only...but also..." structure in English.
就业 (jiùyè) refers specifically to finding paid work or employment. It’s distinct from general terms for working or having an occupation.
赛 (sài) has multiple meanings, including competition, match, and to surpass.  Pay attention to the context to determine the correct interpretation.
This refers to organised groups of people with a shared interest or profession.
This is a very specific term referring to the first meal of the day.
立场 (lìchǎng) refers to a viewpoint, stance, or perspective. It is usually used with 站 (zhàn) as in 站立场 (take a position).
電 (diàn) has various meanings related to electricity, electric shock, and communication. It can function as a noun, verb, or adjective.  The specific meaning depends on the context.
This refers specifically to making up missed classes or lessons, typically due to absence or scheduling conflicts.
This phrase is literary in nature (书面).  It's often used metaphorically to describe something pure, innocent, or unsullied, not just literally free of dust.

This is similar to 不但, but there is a slight difference in usage.  Both are usually followed by a second clause, introduced by 而且 or 并且, etc.  The main difference is that 不但 is slightly more emphatic, expressing surprise or contrast, while 不仅仅 simply states that more than one condition or item is involved.  不仅仅 also has the option to be followed by 是, which 不但 does not.

While 遭遇 can mean a simple encounter, it often carries a negative connotation, suggesting an unfortunate or unpleasant experience. It's often used with words like  不幸 (bùxìng, unfortunate) or  灾难 (zāinàn, disaster).

Although 券 can refer to various types of certificates or tickets, it is becoming increasingly less common in modern usage, especially in Mainland China.  More specific terms like 票 (piào - ticket), 优惠券 (yōuhuìquàn - coupon), or 证件 (zhèngjiàn - certificate) are generally preferred.
This implies using *physical* strength or effort.  For mental or abstract effort, try  努力 (nǔlì) or  加油 (jiāyóu).
While 班长 can refer to a monitor in a school setting, it can also mean a squad leader in a military context or team leader in more general situations.
Be aware of the differences in usage with  高烧 (gāoshāo). 高温 refers to a high temperature in the environment or of an object, while 高烧 specifically refers to a high body temperature due to illness.
This word can describe people or things, but can also carry a sense of seductiveness or allure, so be mindful of context.

The meaning of 院长 depends heavily on context.  It can refer to the head of various institutions, from hospitals and universities to research institutes and even orphanages.  Always consider the surrounding context to determine the specific meaning.
This is generally interchangeable with 包含 (bāohán), but 含有 emphasizes that something is a constituent part or ingredient, whereas 包含 suggests a broader sense of inclusion.
This specifically refers to rent for a house or room.  For other types of rent, use 租金 (zūjīn).
This implies a more significant and potentially life-changing opportunity, unlike 机会 (jīhuì), which can refer to any chance or opportunity, big or small.
随 has many meanings.  Be aware of its use in the structure "随... [verb]", meaning "to do [verb] as one pleases," as in 随便吃 (suíbiàn chī - eat whatever you like).
This refers specifically to academic credits earned towards a degree.
This refers to larger electrical appliances, like refrigerators or washing machines.  For smaller devices, use 电子产品 (diànzǐ chǎnpǐn) or 电子设备 (diànzǐ shèbèi).
This term refers specifically to a large-scale international exhibition or fair.
This term is often used in official contexts to refer to the entire compulsory education system.
Aside from its temporal meaning, 先后 can also indicate order of importance or precedence.

科 has a wide range of meanings. In an academic context, it usually refers to a field of study or academic department.  It can also refer to a family in taxonomy or even a section within a government or organization.
Note that directions in Chinese are typically said with the latitude first, then the longitude (North-South then East-West).
依照 is more formal and often used in written or legal contexts, while 按照 (ànzhào) is more common in spoken language.

跟随 emphasizes closely following or accompanying someone, often implying a subordinate relationship.  This is different from simply going together with someone, which is better expressed with 跟 (gēn) or  一起 (yīqǐ).
假日 is a more formal term for holiday.  For casual conversation, 节日 (jiérì) or  假期 (jiàqī) are more common.
死亡 is a more formal and direct term for death.  In casual conversation or when speaking about someone's passing with sensitivity, more euphemistic terms like 去世 (qùshì) are preferred.
This refers specifically to balls made of leather or rubber.  For balls in general, use 球 (qiú).
This term specifically refers to a point in the past. It's more colloquial than 当时 (dāngshí) or 那时候 (nà shíhòu).
库 can refer to various storage places, from a library (especially for historical documents) to a warehouse or even a computer database.
This often highlights the inherent nature or quality of something, distinct from external factors.
图画 is a more general term, often used with children.  For more sophisticated artworks, use  绘画 (huìhuà) or  画作 (huàzuò).
This implies a process of evaluation and selection, usually involving multiple candidates and a group of judges or voters.  It's more formal than simply choosing.
集 (jí) is a counter specifically used for episodes of a TV show or radio program.
证 has two main usages. One relates to proof or evidence (证据 zhèngjù), and the other to certificates or licenses (证件 zhèngjiàn). Context is crucial for understanding which meaning is intended.
This phrase is colloquial and emphasizes an inability to do something due to limitations or circumstances.
处处 implies not just "everywhere" physically, but also "in every aspect" or "all the time."
脱离 implies a complete separation or disconnection, often from a group, an ideology, or reality.
In mainland China, 爱人 (àiren) usually refers to one's spouse.  Elsewhere, or in older usage, it can mean "lover."
冰雪 can refer literally to ice and snow, but it can also be used figuratively to describe something pure or pristine.
往来 suggests reciprocal actions or communication, a back-and-forth exchange.
This refers to Northeast China (Manchuria), a distinct geographical and cultural region.  It should not be confused with simply the direction "northeast."
火灾 refers specifically to a large, destructive fire, often a disaster. For smaller fires, use simply 火 (huǒ).
This word can also be used to mean "between a certain period of time", in constructions like 一两天之间, or 两三年之间.
This word has a slightly more formal connotation than 偏向.
通行 can be used as an adjective to describe something that is "in circulation", "current" or "prevalent". For example, 通行证 is a "pass", and 通行本 is a "current edition".
The word 循环 is usually used to describe natural processes that repeat over and over, like the water cycle (水循环). For man-made things, the word usually used is 循环.
The more colloquial word for this is 提供 (tígōng).
Measure word for 鞋 is either 双 (shuāng) or 只 (zhī).  双 is usually used for a pair, 只 is used for a single shoe.  So you can say either 一双鞋, or 一只鞋.
Measure word for 墨水 is 瓶 (píng).
There is no difference in usage between 童年 (tóngnián) and childhood.
The difference between 男性 (nánxìng) and 男人 (nánrén) is that 男性 is a more formal word, and also refers to "masculinity" as a concept.
家电 (jiādiàn) is a short form of 家用电器 (jiāyòng diànqì)
全都 (quándōu) has the same usage as 都 (dōu). It's just a little more emphatic.
名额 (míng'é) is usually used to describe a quota or limit of some sort, rather than the place itself.  It's often used with verbs like 限制 (xiànzhì), like this:  限制名额 (xiànzhì míng'é).
Measure word for 江 is either 条 (tiáo) or 道 (dào).
Measure word for 遗产 (yíchǎn) is 笔 (bǐ).
足以 (zúyǐ) is often followed by an adjective, verb, or clause. For example, 足以证明 (zúyǐ zhèngmíng) means "sufficient to prove".
飞 (fēi) is usually used for birds and insects. For airplanes, the word usually used is 航班 (hángbān).
There's no difference in meaning between 北极 (běijí) and the Arctic.
维护 (wéihù) emphasizes the aspect of "maintaining" or "preserving", while 保护 (bǎohù) simply means to "protect" in general.  维护 has a slightly more formal register than 保护.
笑声 (xiàoshēng) and laughter have the same meaning.
The Dragon Boat Festival falls on the 5th day of the 5th lunar month.
用于 (yòngyú) is usually followed by a noun or noun phrase, like 用于治疗 (yòngyú zhìliáo), which means "used for treatment".
共 (gòng) means "in all", and can be used like the word "total" in English.  It's similar to 总共 (zǒnggòng).
薯片 (shǔpiàn) refers to potato chips.  For "chips" made of other root vegetables, you can use the specific root vegetable name.
更换 (gēnghuàn) is a more formal version of 换 (huàn)
含量 (hánliàng) is used specifically for the proportion of a component, often used in technical or scientific contexts.
中央 (zhōngyāng) refers to either the central point of something, or the central government of a country.
Measure word for 弯 is 道 (dào), e.g. 一个弯 (yīgè wān).
信箱 (xìnxiāng) can refer to both a mailbox and a post office box.

待 (dài) is a multi-purpose word. The most common uses are:<NEWLINE>* To stay:  e.g. 我待在家 (wǒ dài zài jiā) - I stay at home<NEWLINE>* To treat:  e.g.  我待你很好 (wǒ dài nǐ hěn hǎo) - I treat you well<NEWLINE>* About to:  e.g.  我待会儿去 (wǒ dài huìr qù) - I'm about to go
时机 (shíjī) refers to an opportune moment or a good chance to do something.  It differs from 时间 (shíjiān), which means "time" in general.
修 (xiū) has many meanings, so understanding its meaning from context is usually crucial.
Measure word for 事故 (shìgù) are 桩 (zhuāng), 起 (qǐ), and 次 (cì).
少儿 (shào'ér) is usually used to talk about children in a formal or literary context.  In spoken Chinese, 孩子 (háizi) or 小孩 (xiǎohái) are more common.
研制 (yánzhì) is usually used to talk about researching and manufacturing complex technological products.
做到 (zuòdào) highlights the process or the effort required to reach a specific goal or standard, while 做 (zuò) simply means to "do" something.
客车 (kèchē) can also mean passenger train.
烟花 (yānhuā) can also refer to a prostitute, especially in the context of Yuan dynasty theatre.
地上 (dìshàng) contrasts with 地下 (dìxià), which means underground.
开启 (kāiqǐ) is more formal than 打开 (dǎkāi), and often implies starting something new, or opening something that has been closed for a long time.
Measure word for 皇帝 (huángdì) is 个 (gè).

拖 can be used as a noun, meaning something that impedes progress or creates a burden. For example, 拖油瓶 (tuōyóupíng) means "burden" or "impediment," often referring to a child from a previous marriage.
黑色 can sometimes carry a negative connotation, implying illegal or shady activities, such as  "black market" (黑市 - hēishì) or "blackmail" (黑社会- hēishèhuì).
奉献 is a rather formal and high-minded word, often used in contexts of patriotism, service, or religious devotion.  It implies selfless giving and contribution.

When specifying the contents, 箱 is typically followed by the measure word 的 (de), e.g.,  一箱的苹果 (yī xiāng de píngguǒ) - a box of apples.  However, when the contents are clearly defined by context, 的 can be omitted, e.g.,  帮我搬一下箱子 (bāng wǒ bān yīxià xiāngzi) - help me move the box (implied: the box we are both aware of).
吸 is also used figuratively to mean "attract" or "draw in," as in 吸引 (xīyǐn) - attract, absorb.
飞行 can be used as a verb even without an object.  For example,  鸟在飞行 (niǎo zài fēixíng) - birds are flying.

上次 is also used to express regret or disappointment about a missed opportunity. For instance, the sentence "上次你没来真可惜" (Shàngcì nǐ méi lái zhēn kěxí) translates to "It's a pity you didn't come last time."
打造 emphasizes the process of creating something carefully and skillfully, often implying high quality or craftsmanship.

策略 is more about the skillful maneuvering and clever planning involved in achieving a goal, often with an element of cunning or shrewdness.  It is related to the word 策 (cè) which means plan or scheme.
扭 can also mean "to turn" (e.g., a doorknob or a key) or to "swing one's hips" while walking.
The most common pronunciation of 勺 is "sháo." It's also pronounced "zhuó," but this primarily occurs within certain compounds like 舀 (yǎo - to ladle, to scoop)
创办 implies establishing something new and original, often an organization, business, or publication.
摩托 is a shortened form of 摩托车 (mótuōchē), so it already includes the meaning of "vehicle." It's not necessary to add 车 after it.
搜 can be used in combination with other verbs to create more specific search actions, like 搜查 (sōuchá - to search a place), 搜身 (sōushēn - to frisk someone), or 搜集 (sōují - to collect information).
巩固 usually refers to strengthening something that's already established, rather than building something entirely new.
天 can also be used in a metaphorical sense for something exceptional, as in 天才 (tiāncái) "genius."
上个月 can also be used metaphorically to denote a relatively short time ago, in casual conversations.
越来越 typically requires a descriptive complement or adjective after it. You cannot say "越来越人" (yuè lái yuè rén); instead, you would say "人越来越多" (rén yuè lái yuè duō) – "more and more people."
In Northern China, 汽水 is usually a sweet carbonated drink similar to soda or lemonade, however in Southern China 汽水 often refers to any carbonated drink.
运行 often implies a continuous and regular movement or operation, especially in the context of systems, processes, or celestial bodies.
定时 can also function as an adjective, meaning "regular" or "periodic," such as in 定时航班 (dìngshí hángbān) – "regular flight."
下个月 can also be used in a metaphorical sense to refer to the near future, not necessarily literally the next month.
演 can also mean to "develop," as in a situation or story evolving. For instance, the sentence "事情会怎么演变?" (Shìqíng huì zěnme yǎnbiàn?) means "How will the situation develop?"
不易 also carries the connotation of "unchanging" or "invariable."
歌声 often describes the general quality or atmosphere of singing, as opposed to just the sound of a voice.
逃跑 is an intransitive verb meaning to flee or escape by running. It is often interchangeable with 逃 (táo), but focuses specifically on fleeing.
赔 also carries the connotation of "to suffer a loss," not just to compensate someone else. For example, 赔钱 (péiqián) means "to lose money."
适当 suggests finding the right balance or degree, often implying moderation or avoiding extremes.
整整 emphasizes the completeness or fullness of a duration or quantity.
豆腐 (dòufu – tofu) is the most famous and prototypical example of 豆制品.  It's used in a vast array of dishes across Chinese cuisine.
黄色 can have a sexual or pornographic connotation in certain contexts. It's a euphemism for pornography, derived from the association of yellow with sensuality or eroticism in some cultures.
运作 refers to the mechanisms and processes through which something operates or functions. It often emphasizes the behind-the-scenes aspects of making something work effectively.
困扰 suggests a persistent or recurring problem that causes worry or difficulty.
例外 is frequently used in the expression 没有例外 (méiyǒu lìwài) - "no exceptions."
泥 can have slightly different meanings based on context:  泥 (ní) generally refers to mud or clay, while  泥巴 (níba) specifically refers to the sticky kind of mud that children play with.
违法 is more formal and generally refers to breaking a specific law.
出去 often implies going somewhere relatively far or for an extended period, compared to other words like 出门 (chūmén - to go out [of the house]).
老头儿 is a colloquial and sometimes affectionate term for "old man." It can also be slightly derogatory depending on tone and context.

女朋友 can also be used politely to refer to a female friend, similar to how "boyfriend" can sometimes be used ambiguously in English.  To be absolutely clear you are referring to a romantic partner, add  "我的"  (wǒde - my).

There's not much difference between 人群 (rénqún) and the English word "crowd." However, note that 人群 is more of a neutral term. It doesn't necessarily imply a large, dense, or unruly gathering like "mob" or "horde" might.  It simply refers to a group of people.

演唱 (yǎnchàng) is more formal than 唱歌 (chànggē), and often implies a public performance for an audience. It usually suggests a higher level of skill or professionalism.  唱歌 is more general and can be used for singing in any context, including karaoke, showering, etc.

多种 (duō zhǒng) emphasizes variety within a category, while 多 (duō) simply means "many" or "much".  For example, 多种水果 (duō zhǒng shuǐguǒ) means "many kinds of fruit," highlighting the variety, while 多水果 (duō shuǐguǒ) means "a lot of fruit," focusing on quantity.

不要 (bùyào) can function as both "don't" and "must not" depending on the context. It expresses prohibition.  To express a lack of desire, use 不想 (bùxiǎng).  For example,  我不想吃 (wǒ bùxiǎng chī) means "I don't want to eat," whereas 不要吃 (bùyào chī) means "Don't eat!"
海湾 (hǎiwān) is a general term for a body of water partially enclosed by land. It can be translated as either "bay" or "gulf" depending on its size.  Generally, a gulf is larger than a bay.

网吧 (wǎngbā) has become less common with increased home internet access.  Now, you might see more 网咖 (wǎngkā), short for 网络咖啡厅 (wǎngluò kāfēitīng), "internet cafe."  These are often more upscale and focus on gaming and esports.

As a verb, 折 (zhé) in Chinese has an extremely diverse range of meanings related to bending, breaking and changing shape.  You'll need to pay close attention to context to figure out its specific application.

出路 (chūlù) carries a more significant connotation than simply a "way out." It often refers to a path towards a better future, a solution to a difficult situation, or a chance for advancement.  A more literal "way out" would be simply 出口 (chūkǒu).
近日 (jìnrì) is less precise than "in the past few days." It refers to the general period of "recently" or "in recent days," and can even occasionally refer to the near future (the next few days).
流感 (liúgǎn) specifically refers to influenza, not just any flu.  For a more general "flu" or cold, use 感冒 (gǎnmào).
补考 (bǔkǎo) implies a second chance to pass a failed exam, not an additional exam to improve one's grade.

却是 (quèshì) introduces a contrasting thought or an unexpected fact. It's closer to "however," "nevertheless," or "actually" rather than a simple "yes, it is."  For a simple confirmation, use 的确 (díquè) or 确实是 (quèshí shì).

红包 (hóngbāo) is more than just a red envelope; it signifies the cultural practice of giving monetary gifts, especially during holidays and special occasions. It carries strong cultural connotations of good luck and blessings.
返回 (fǎnhuí) implies returning to a starting point, whereas 回去 (huíqù) is more general and can mean simply "go back."  Also, 返回 is slightly more formal.
惊人 (jīngrén) can be positive or negative, describing something that is either astonishingly good or alarmingly bad. Context is essential to determine the intended meaning.
In mainland China, 白酒 (báijiǔ) almost exclusively refers to strong distilled spirits, typically made from sorghum. In Taiwan, however, it can also mean "white wine" (like Chardonnay).

走开 (zǒukāi) has a stronger, more dismissive tone than simply saying "leave."  It's often used to tell someone to go away because they're annoying or unwanted.  A more polite way to ask someone to leave is 请离开 (qǐng líkāi).
注视 (zhùshì) implies a prolonged and focused gaze, indicating close observation or scrutiny.  It differs from 看 (kàn), which is a more general term for "look" or "see."
起 (qǐ) has an extraordinarily wide range of meanings and uses as a verb. Context is always crucial.
捕 (bǔ) is usually used for catching living things like animals or criminals.  For catching inanimate objects, use 接 (jiē) or other more specific verbs.
崇拜 (chóngbài) has religious connotations and implies deep admiration and reverence.  It's stronger than simply 喜欢 (xǐhuan) or 欣赏 (xīnshǎng).
一道 (yīdào) when meaning "together" emphasizes doing something in unison or as a group.
战术 (zhànshù) are short-term, specific plans, whereas 战略 (zhànlüè) refers to long-term, grand strategies.
广阔 (guǎngkuò) emphasizes physical vastness or breadth, whereas 宽广 (kuānguǎng) can also refer to abstract concepts like a broad mind or a wide range of knowledge.
长期 (chángqí) is usually used for periods lasting months, years, or even decades.  For shorter durations like days or weeks, use 短期 (duǎnqí).
动手 (dòngshǒu) can mean to start working on something (often physical work), but it can also mean "to lay hands on" or to initiate a physical fight.
红茶 (hóngchá) is "black tea" in English, not "red tea."  This can be a common point of confusion for English speakers.
指数 (zhǐshù) usually refers to a numerical index showing relative change over time. It is not used for simple ordinal numbers (like first, second, third, etc.).
注重 (zhùzhòng) emphasizes giving something focused attention and importance.  It's stronger than simply 注意 (zhùyì), which means to "pay attention" in general.
防止 (fángzhǐ) means to take preventative measures against something negative happening.  It differs from 避免 (bìmiǎn) which means to personally avoid something.
成效 (chéngxiào) focuses on positive and tangible results, whereas 效果 (xiàoguǒ) is more general and can refer to any outcome, either good or bad.

下次 (xià cì) is "next time", whereas 下一次 (xià yī cì) puts specific emphasis on the ordinal nature of the event.  It means, specifically, the *next* time. The inclusion of 一 (yī - one) adds this extra layer of specificity.
开设 (kāishè) implies establishing or founding something new, often a business, course, or service.  It's more formal than simply 开 (kāi) which means "to open".
热门 (rèmén) emphasizes something being trendy or in vogue, whereas 流行 (liúxíng) describes something that is widely spread or prevalent.
认可 (rènkě) suggests formal acceptance or acknowledgment, possibly even official certification.  It's more formal and official than 承认 (chéngrèn).
策划 (cèhuà) implies detailed planning and strategizing, often for a complex project or event.  It's more comprehensive than simply 计划 (jìhuà) to plan.
具有 (jùyǒu) emphasizes a characteristic quality or inherent property of something.  It's more formal than simply 有 (yǒu) "to have."
依赖 (yīlài) can carry a negative connotation of over-reliance or dependence, whereas 依靠 (yīkào) is more neutral.
Can be used figuratively to mean "a headache" or "a nuisance". For example, 对我来说, 这真是个头疼的问题 (This is a real headache for me).
This word is specifically used for hosting large events such as conferences or sporting events, and is not used for smaller events such as parties.  A more general word would be 举办 (jǔbàn).

桃花 can be used figuratively to refer to a romantic relationship or love interest, often in a slightly humorous or teasing way. For example, saying someone has good 桃花 means they have good luck with love.

The word 处 (chù) has many meanings.  Be careful to distinguish the meanings related to location (place, spot, point, office, department) from the meanings related to human relationships (to get along with, to deal with, to discipline, to punish.)
偷偷摸摸 (tōutōumōmō) emphasizes the secretive and cautious nature of the action, often suggesting a sense of guilt or fear of being discovered.
The measure word for 二维码 is 个 (gè).
More formal than 上班 (shàngbān) which just means "to go to work".  办公 might involve meetings, writing reports, etc.
Just 熊猫 is fine in most situations.  大熊猫 is more formal, or used when disambiguation is needed.
Can also refer to handheld gaming devices.
剧 can refer to different forms of theatrical works and not just plays. It can also be used to describe a significant change or a severe situation.
This word refers to any member of a ship's crew, not just sailors.  It can include cooks, engineers, etc.
This can refer to both the game and the ball itself. Context is important.

This word implies not only feasible but also effectively implemented.  It's not enough that something *could* work; it *must* work.  切实可行 (qièshíkěxíng), meaning truly feasible, is a common collocation.
Figuratively, 暴风雨 can represent any tumultuous or chaotic situation, similar to "storm" in English.
Specifically refers to father and son.  母女 is mother and daughter.  父母 is parents.
This emphasizes practical skill and technique, often learned through practice, rather than theoretical knowledge.
This implies a more gradual realization or discovery, often of something subtle or previously unnoticed.
While it can refer to any adult, it is often used respectfully when addressing someone older or of higher status.
The measure word for 袋 is 个 (gè).
共计 is more formal and often used in official reports, financial documents, or similar contexts.  总共 (zǒnggòng) is more common in everyday speech.
This is more colloquial than 这里.
In a digital context, this means "to log out".
Also 星期天.
Can also mean the immediate vicinity or surroundings.
The most common way to wish someone good luck.
This term can encompass a wider range of visual productions, including short films, documentaries, and animated features, not just movies.
Often followed by a verb phrase indicating an involuntary action or emotion.
This can also have political connotations, referring to communism or revolution.
This emphasizes secondary or supportive assistance, not primary action.
Often used as a suffix to indicate nationality (e.g., 中国人, 美国人).
Can also refer to the general area around a doorway or entrance.
The focus is on increasing the pace or speed of something already in progress, rather than starting something new.
Specifically refers to the second-place winner.  季军 is third place.
Indicates a high probability but not absolute certainty.
压 can have multiple meanings, some related to physical pressure and some related to controlling or suppressing something.  It is also used in some colloquial expressions.
This often implies the mobilization of a significant force or resource, not just a single person or vehicle.
睡着 emphasizes the state of being asleep, whereas 睡觉 (shuìjiào) refers to the act of sleeping.
Refers to official documents or certifications, not just any certificate.
Specifically refers to an increase in price or value.  上升 (shàngshēng) is more general.
Can also refer to a final destination or goal, not just the end of a race.

签订 (qiāndìng) is a formal word, often used in legal or official contexts, for signing agreements, contracts, or treaties.  While it can sometimes be translated simply as "sign," it carries a stronger connotation of formal agreement and commitment.  More casual alternatives for signing something might be 签 (qiān) or 签字 (qiān zì).

事件 (shìjiàn) refers to an incident, event, or happening, often with a negative or noteworthy connotation.  It can imply something unexpected or of public interest.  For more mundane or everyday occurrences, you might use 事情 (shìqing).

这 (zhè) is a versatile word with a few key uses.  It functions as a demonstrative pronoun ("this," "these"), a determiner modifying nouns, and a pronoun in certain contexts. Pay attention to how it combines with measure words and nouns. For example,  这只猫 (zhè zhī māo) "this cat."

歌唱 (gēchàng) is a more formal and literary word for singing than 唱歌 (chànggē).  It's often used in contexts like discussing musical performances, artistic expression, or praising someone's vocal abilities.

总量 (zǒngliàng) specifically refers to the total quantity or amount of something.  While 总数 (zǒngshù) also means "total," it is generally used for countable nouns, whereas 总量 is for uncountable quantities or mass nouns.
亲人 (qīnrén) refers to close relatives, often implying a strong emotional bond.  It's more intimate than 家人 (jiārén), which means family members and can include more distant relations.
读者 (dúzhě) means "reader," typically referring to someone who reads books, magazines, or other written material.  It can refer to a specific reader or a general readership.
图书 (túshū) is a more formal and comprehensive term for books and written materials than 书 (shū).  It's often used in contexts like libraries, publishing, or academic discussions.
There's no significant difference between 贴纸 (tiēzhǐ) and "sticker" in English usage.
地形 (dìxíng) refers to the physical features and shape of the land surface, encompassing both natural formations and man-made alterations.
水产品 (shuǐchǎnpǐn) refers to a broad category of products harvested from bodies of water, including fish, shellfish, seaweed, and other aquatic organisms.

以上 (yǐshàng) can mean "above," "over," or "more than" when referring to quantities or levels.  It can also mean "the above-mentioned" when summarizing previous points.  Finally, it can signal the conclusion of a speech or statement, similar to "that is all."
社 (shè) can mean "society," "organization," or "agency." It is often used as a suffix in organization names. In older Chinese, it also referred to the god of the land.
照相 (zhàoxiàng) and 拍照 (pāizhào) both mean "to take a photo."  照相 is slightly older and more traditional, while 拍照 is more common in modern usage.
团体 (tuántǐ) generally refers to a group or organization of people with a shared purpose or interest. It often implies a more formal or structured group than 小组 (xiǎozǔ), which means "small group."

应对 (yìngduì) implies dealing with or responding to a situation, often a challenge or problem.  It suggests taking action to address something.  It's more formal than 处理 (chǔlǐ), which also means "to handle" or "deal with."
No special notes.
No special notes.
No special notes.

潮 (cháo) has multiple meanings, including "tide," "damp/moist," and "trendy/fashionable." Be aware of the different contexts.  In some colloquial contexts, it can also mean "inferior" or "substandard," but this usage is less common.
后 (hòu) is a versatile word meaning "back," "behind," "after," "later," and can also refer to an empress or queen.  Pay attention to context to determine the intended meaning.
革新 (géxīn) implies significant and transformative change or innovation, often in systems or institutions.  It's more substantial than simply 改革 (gǎigé), which means "reform."
No special notes.
No special notes.
Often used with the verb 看 (kàn), as in 看眼熟 (kàn yǎnshu).

The meaning "crosspiece" is only used for furniture like tables, shelves, etc. meaning the horizontal crosspieces. Don't use it for something like the crosspiece of a crucifix. When used to mean "vendor's open-air stall," it is usually reduplicated as 档档 (dàngdàng).
No special notes.
Be careful about word order.  过于 always comes *before* the adjective or adverb it modifies. For example, “too expensive” is  过于昂贵 (guòyú ánguì), *not* 昂贵过于 (ánguì guòyú).
No special notes.

Can function as a noun, meaning "the middle."  In this context, it's often used with the preposition 在 (zài) to create the phrase 在…当中 (zài... dāngzhōng).  For example, 在人群当中 (zài rénqún dāngzhōng) means "in the middle of the crowd."
就算 is stronger than 即使 (jíshǐ) or 哪怕 (nǎpà).  It conveys a feeling of concession, as if the speaker is reluctantly admitting something to be true for the sake of argument.
Can be used as a prefix before other words to form compounds that specifically refer to men's fashion, restrooms, and so on.
No special notes.
No special notes.
The resultative complement 成 (chéng) emphasizes completion of the construction project.
No special notes.
No special notes.
Can be used more broadly than "moving" or "touching" in English.  It can also describe something beautiful or captivating.
Can also be used as a noun, meaning "fee" or "charge."
No special notes.
No special notes.
When used as a suffix for locations, it adds a sense of vagueness or approximation, like "nearby" or "around." For example, "outside" can be 外边 (wàibian), with 边 having this nuance.
No special notes.
Implies a sense of urgency, suggesting that something needs to be done quickly because of a pressing situation.
Figuratively, it can refer to any fiercely competitive or challenging environment, such as a "commercial battlefield" (商业战场 shāngyè zhànchǎng).
No special notes.
Can describe not only material wealth but also abundance in abstract qualities.
No special notes.
In the sense of "about" or "approximately," 上下 is placed *after* the number it modifies.
A more formal and stronger term than 责任 (zérèn), implying a sense of assigned duty and accountability, often in a professional or official context.
No special notes.
When referring to the act of sending a voice message, the term 语音 is often combined with the verb 发 (fā) to form the phrase 发语音 (fā yǔyīn), which means "to send a voice message."
Has many specific meanings depending on context.
Implies a sudden and powerful force, often causing significant disturbance or change.
Can also refer to the way something is presented or marketed, especially the visual aspects like design and labeling.
No special notes.
Can refer to a variety of thin, flexible materials, not just biological membranes.
Often used in formal contexts, such as academic discussions or official reports, to highlight a specific fact, error, or issue.
No special notes.
Can be used as an exclamation of admiration or appreciation, similar to "Wonderful!" or "Brilliant!" in English.
Often used with the measure word 个 (gè).
Can be used figuratively to describe someone who is mischievous or restless.
Implies exceeding a limit or boundary, often with negative connotations, suggesting something is beyond what's allowed or expected.
Often used together with the word 软件 (ruǎnjiàn), which means "software," to form the term 杀毒软件 (shādú ruǎnjiàn), which means "antivirus software."
Formal written style essays are typically referred to as 散文.  More informal essays, such as those written by students, are called 作文 (zuòwén).

This can be tricky to use correctly. When referring to all of a group of people, 全 should be placed *before* the measure word, e.g. 全家人 (quánjiārén), 全班同学 (quánbān tóngxué). However, if there is no measure word, 全 should be placed *after* the noun. For example, we say "the whole world" as 全世界 (quánshìjiè).
In addition to meaning "a good person", 好人 can also have a sarcastic meaning, referring to someone who is too afraid of offending others to act according to their principles.
儿 (er) is a retroflex suffix which makes the tone gentler and more urging.
共有 is most often used in the written language.
至 is a more formal way of saying 到 (dào).
此次 is more formal than 这次 (zhè cì).
登山 is the act of climbing a mountain as a sport or leisure activity. For ascending a mountain as a means of transport, use 上山 (shàngshān).
Only used to invite someone *in*. To invite someone to go first, use 您先 (nín xiān).
遇 has the nuance of something happening unexpectedly.
This word is mostly used in a scientific context.  In more informal settings, 太空人 (tàikōngrén) is preferred.
常年 can refer to all seasons of the year, or it can refer to the average value of something over many years.
沟 is somewhat formal.  More informal synonyms include 水沟 (shuǐgōu) and 水渠 (shuǐqú).
替 means to replace someone, implying they are not present.  If someone is present and you're doing their work for them, use 帮 (bāng) instead.
回国 is used only for returning to one's *own* country.  To go back to any other country, use 回 (huí).

A related word is 学生 (xuéshēng). In general, 徒弟 (túdì) emphasizes the master-apprentice relationship, where skills and knowledge are passed down through personal training and mentorship. It carries a sense of tradition and lineage. On the other hand, 学生 (xuéshēng) emphasizes the teacher-student relationship, which can be more formal and institutionalized.
